editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

notesStmt.note: 'The English moor' (E.1782[1]) and 'The love-sick court'(E.1782[2]) have separate title pages, continuous pagination and register, and a final leaf of epilogue. 'Covent Garden weeded' (E.1782[3]) and 'The nevv academy' (E.1782[4]) have separate title pages, continous register, separate pagination, and a final leaf of advertisements. 'Covent garden weeded' has t.p. which reads: 'The weeding of the Covent-Garden'. 'The queen and concubine' (E.1782[5]) has its own t.p., continous pagination and register, and a final leaf of advertisements.

Annotations on Thomason copies: (E.1782[1]; general titlepage): "Jan"; the '9' in the imprint has been crossed out and replaced with an "8"; (E. 1782[3]: "Jan: January"; (E. 1782[5]): "Jan"; the '9' in the imprint has been crossed out and replaced with an "8".
Reproductions of the originals in the British Library.

div.p:
Five new plays, viz.
The English Moor, or the mock-marriage.
The lovesick court, or the ambitious Politique.
Covent garden weeded.
The new academy, or the new exchange.
The Queen and concubine.
London, printed for A. Crook at the green dragon in saint Paul's churchyard, and for H. Brome at the gun in ivy-lane, 1659.

div.head: To the readers.
div.p:
Or rather to the spectators, if the fates so pleased, these comedies exactly being dressed for the stage; and the often-tried author (Better than many who can but scribble) understood the proportions and beauties of a scene; but as they are they will not deceive you; for the same hand (Which formerly pleased) now held the pen. We suppose we bring what in these days you scarce could hope for, five
new plays we call them new, because till now they never were printed. You must not think them posthumous productions, though they come into the world after the author's death: they were all begotten and born (And owned by him before a thousand witnesses) many years since; they then trod the stage (Their proper place) though they passed not the press. They are all comedies, for (A man would think) we have had too many tragedies. But this book knew them not. The English Moor here ( whatever name or face it wears) is older than our troubles. The lovesick court, and the ambitious politic are but one play, though strange those two should dwell together. This new academy concerns not that which eight years since peeped up in write friars; and this new exchange knows nothing
of that which now is cleaving to the great church wall. This Queen is a mere stranger to our island; her scene is Sicily, the persons and action taste nothing of England. Thus the whole book being free and ingenuous, we hope the author may have the same allowance, especially now since he's gone to the great wits, that is, dead. And yet there are a sort (One would wonder there should be) who think they lessen this author's worth when they speak the relation he had to Ben Johnson. We very thankfully embrace the objection, and desire they would name any other master that could better teach a man to write a good play. The materials must flow from all parts of the world; but the art and composition come only from books and such living masters as that our great laureate; and for this purpose we have here prefixed Ben Johnson's own
testimony to his servant our author; we grant it is (According to Ben's own nature and custom) magisterial enough; and who looks for other, since he said to Shakespeare — I shall draw envy on thy name (By writing in his praise) and threw in his face — small Latin and less greek; but also told Selden himself (As if ben's conscience checked him for being too good natured in commending others.)

quote.l: Your book (My Selden) I have read —
Though I confess (As every muse hath erred,
And mine not least) I have too oft preferred
Men passed their terms, and praised some names too much,
But 'twas with purpose to have made them such;
Since, being deceived, I turn a sharper eye
Upon myself, and ask to whom, and why,
And what I write, and vex it many days
Before men get a verse, much less a praise.
— I first salute thee so, and gratulates,
With that thy style, thy keeping of thy state.
— I could take up (And never abuse
The credit) what would furnish a tenth muse ▪
But here's nor time nor place my wealth to tell;
You both are modest, so am I. Farewell.

div.p:
It seems ( whate'er we think) Ben thought it diminution for no man to attend upon his muse. And were not already the ancients too much trod on, we could name famous wits who served far meaner masters than Ben Johnson. For, none versed in letters but know the wise Aesop was born and bred a wretched slave; Lucian a stone-cutter, Virgil himself begotten by a basketmaker, born in a ditch, and then preferred to an under groom in the stable; nay, (To instance in our authors own order) Naevius the comedian a captain's man's man; Plautus
servant to a poor baker, Terence a slave as well as Aesop; and (Which for our purpose is most of all) our authors own master handled the trowel before he grew acquainted with Sejanus or Cataline. But enough of this, lest pleading for the author, make him seem to want an apology. As for the stationers, they bring these poems as they had them from the author; not suffering any false or busy hand to add or make the least mutilation; having been more watchful over the printers common negligence, than such work as this hath usually obtained. And if these new plays fail your expectation, we openly profess we know not how, where, or when we shall fit you.

div.head: To my old faithful servant, and (By his continued virtue) my loving friend, the author of this work, Mr. Rich. Brome.
div.l: I had you for a servant, once, Dick. Brome,
And you performed a servant's faithful parts:
Now, you are got into a nearer room
Of fellowship, professing my old arts.
And you do do them well, with good applause,
Which you have justly gained from the stage,
By observation of those comic laws,
Which I, your master, first did teach this age.
You learned it well, and for it served your time,
A prenticeship, which few do now adays:
Now each court. Hobby-horse, will wince in rhyme.
Both learned and unlearned, all write plays:
It was not so of old; men took up trades
That knew the crafts they had been bred in right;
An honest bilbo smith would make good blades,
And the physician teach men spew, and —
The cobbler kept him to his awl, but now
He'll be a pilot, scarce can guide a blow.

div.head: To my most ingenious friend, Mr. alex. Brome upon his setting forth Mr. Rich. Brome's plays:
div.l: This, sir, is double piety, and you
In this oblige the dead and living too.
As the last trumpet with one powerful sound
Raises forgotten bodies from the ground,
And betters those that yet remain alive:
So you an equal happiness do give
Unto his dust, and us, at once engage
His sacred ashes, and the present age.
Nor can I tell to whom we more are bound,
Or to his wit, or you that have it found.
When Thetis son amongst the maids lay hidden,
And for their softer wars the Trojan fled;
he that discovered him, did justly claim
An equal share in th' honour of his name;
And dared to call Achilles' victories,
All those exploits, and all those trophies his:
So you that have this noble wit revealed
And made it be (Which was before concealed)
Known and commended, may as well receive
Part in those laurels we to him do give.
He made the oil, but you enlightened it,
He gave the salt, but you have made it white,
And dug it from the pit where it once lay
Unseen, or by the eyes of men or day:
He made the branches of this coral grow,
Hid in its private sea untouched; but you
By drawing it into the open air,
Have made it turn more precious, and more fair.
He spoke with such a full and easy strain,
With such a soft, and such a flowing vein,
As if 'twere nature all, yet there was art,
Yet there was skill in every limb and part.
So gently came all that he thought or writ,
As if he made it not, but did repeat.
His fancy like the blood did always flow,
Yet full of life and full of spirits too.
His wit and angels did in this agree,
Their motion is most nimble, quick, and free,
And perfect too. And as the world was made,
(Which no delays of spring and summer had,
No ages or increases, but on all
At first a ripeness, and full growth did fall;
So all that from his happy pen did come
Was ripe and grown at first, and left no room
For after change, no second hand could give
More strength to it, or it more strength receive.
When he doth speak of love, himself he arms
With such resistless, and such conquering charms,
Acts such sweet hopes, such innocent fears, and joys,
That we or love his mistress, or his voice,
As echo did. When he would make us smile,
Thousand Anacreons play about his style.
When he commands our sorrow, straight our eyes
Into salt streams, our hearts to sighings rise.
When he doth laugh again, the clouds are gone,
our minds into a sudden calmness run:
He so disposed our thoughts, as when the hand,
Or eye of the chief general doth command,
Whole armies act what his example led,
Follow his postures with such willing speed,
Into obedience with such easiness fall,
As if one soul and spring did move them all.
When he struck vice, he let the person go,
Wounded not men but manners; nor did do
Like him who when he painted heaven and hell,
Amongst the damned shades and those that fell,
Did draw his enemy's face, that all might say
Who there condemned by the painter lay:
But as the surgeon at once hides and cures,
And bindeth up the limb which most endures
The sore and pain: so he with gentle hand
Did heal the wound, and yet conceal the man.
His scenes men's actions, tempers, humours show,
And copy out what the great world doth do.
His words are like the shapes which angels take,
And for themselves of finest air do make,
That are so much like men, that clearest eyes
Cannot discern where the small difference lies.

div.p: The English Moor, or the mock-marriage.
A comedy as it was often acted with general applause by her majesty's servants.
div.l: Innocens permit jocos cur ludere nobis
Non liceat? —
div.p: London, printed by J. T. for A. C. and Henry Broom, and are to be sold at the gun in Ivy-lane, 1658.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: Most noble, fair and courteous, to ye all
Welcome and thanks we give, that you would call
And visit your poor servants, that have been
So long and pitiless unheard, unseen.
Welcome, you'll say your money that does do,
(Dissembling is a fault) we say so too.
And your long absence was no fault of your,
But our sad fate to be so long obscure.
Jove and the muses grant, and all good men,
We feel not that extremity again:
The thought of which yet chills us with a fear
That we have bought our liberty too dear:
For should we fall into a new restraint,
Our hearts must break that did before but faint.
You noble, great and good ones, that vouchsafe
To see a comedy, and sometimes laugh
Or smile at wit and harmless mirth, as thus
Ye have begun to grace and succour us;
Be further pleased (To hold us still upright,
For our relief, and for your own delight)
To move for us to those high powers whom we
Submit unto in all humility,
For our proceeding, and we'll make it good
To utter nothing may be understood
Offensive to the state, manners or time,
We will as well look to our necks as climb.
You hear our suit, obtain it if you may;
Then find us money and we'll find you play.

row.cell: Two old gentlemen and friends, supposed to have been killed in a duel.

list.item: Arthur, Meanwel's son, in love with Lucy.
Theophilus, Rashley's son, in love with Milicent.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Dear sister, bear with me.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: I may not, brother.
What! suffer you to pine, and peak away
In your unnatural melancholy fits;
Which have already turned your purer blood
Into a toad-pool die. I am ashamed
(Upon my life) almost to call you brother
But nature has her swing in me. I must.
Therefore I crave you (As you are my brother)
To shake this dull and muddy humour off,
By visiting the streets, and quit your chamber,
Which is a sickness to you.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: O my sister!

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: I can say, oh my brother too, to show you
How it becomes you. I have the same cause
Equally with yourself, to spend my life
In solitary mourning; and would do it,
Could it make good our loss: my honoured father!
A tear has scaped me there: but that's by th'by,
And more of anger 'gainst his enemy,
And his for ever cursed posterity,
That robbed us of a father, then of sorrow
For what we know is unrecoverable.
But to sit grieving over his memory
In a resolved silence, as you do;
Killing your own blood while a vein holds any
Proceeding from the flesh, that drew out his,
Is merely idle. Mingle then your grief
With thought of brave revenge: and do it not
In private meditation in your chamber;
But bear it out till it proceed to action.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: By pouring blood on blood?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: By quenching fire
Of high revenge, with base unmanly blood;
By stopping of our fathers cureless wounds
(Which still bleed fresh in our vexed memories)
With the proud flesh of him that butchered ours.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: We know he lives not that has slain our father:
Or, if he lives, 'tis where I cannot reach him:
He ne'er saw English harbour since his sword
Unfortunately had the better of my father.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: But his son lives.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Good sister cool thy passion
With reasonable means

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: O where's the spirit
That my slain father had. Have you no part of't?
Must I now play the man, whilst you inherit
Only my mother's puling disposition?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I know thy drift, good sister Dionysia,
Is not unto revenge, or blood; but to stir up
Some motion in me, to prevent the danger
A sad retiredness may bring upon me.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Be't as you think it, so you will abroad;
And make the house no longer dark with sighing.
Now sir the news with you?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: News worth your hearing,
Merely to laugh at: good for nothing else.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Is the old ruffian ta'en, and hanged, that slew
My father; or his son brain-battered; or
His daughter made a prostitute to shame?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How merciless are your wishes!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Lady, no.
But as I was hankering at an ordinary,
In quest of a new master (For this, here,
Will never last to a new livery
'Less he were merrier) I heard the bravest noise
Of laughter at a wicked accident
Of marriage, that was chopped up this morning.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: What marriage? Quickly.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Who do you think
Has married fair mistress Millicent?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Theophilus (I can name him, though his father
Was fatal unto mine) was sure to her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes, but without a priest. She has slipped his hold,
And is made fast enough unto another,
For which fine Mr. The. so whines and chafes,
And hangs the head! More than he would do
For's father, were he hanged, as you did wish
For laughing news e'en now. There's sport for you.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: It does me good to hear of any cross
That may torment their family. I wish
Joy to the man that did beguile him of her
Whate'er he be.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: But who has married her?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Thence springs the jest. Old Mr. quicksands, sir,
The bottomless devourer of young gentlemen;
He that has lived, till passed threescore, a bachelor,
By threescore i'the hundred; he that has
Undone by mortgages and under-buyings
So many gentlemen, that they all despaired
of means to be revenged.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: But where's your jest?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: The jest is, that they now have found that means
(As they suppose) by making of him cuckold.
They are laying their heads together in every corner,
Contriving of his horns, and drinking healths
To the success. And there were sport for you now,
If you were anybody .

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I'll abroad however.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: That's nobly said. Take courage with you brother.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: And yet methinks I know not how to look
The wide world in the face, thus on the sudden
I would fain get abroad, yet be unknown.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: For that sir (Look you) I have here, by chance,
A false beard which I borrowed, with a purpose
To ha' worn't and put a jest upon your sadness.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Does it do well with me?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: You'll never have
One of your own so good: you look like Hector.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Go fetch my sword and follow me.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Be sure you carry a strict eye o'er his actions,
And bring me a true account.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I warrant you mistress.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Do, and I'll love thee everlastingly.
Why, now you are my brother.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Farewell sister.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: I hope he has some stratagem a foot
In our revenge to make his honour good:
It is not grief can quit a father's blood.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Prithee be and answered, and hang off o'me,
I ha' no more to say to you in the way
you wot on Phillis.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Nor do I seek to you
In that way which you wot on, wanton sir,
But to be honest, and to marry me.
You have done too much the tother way already.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I wish you were more thankful, Mrs. Phillis,
To one has taught you a trade to live upon:
You are not th'first by twenty I have taught it
That thrive well i'the world.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: There are so many
Such teachers in the world; and so few
Reformers, that the world is grown so full
Of female frailties, the poor harlotries
Can scarce already live by one another,
And yet you would have me thrust in among 'em.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I do not urge you. Take what course you please,
But look not after me: I am not marked
For matrimony, I thank my stars.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Should I run evil courses, you are the cause;
And may in time, curse your own act in it:
You'll find th'undoing of an honest maid
Your heaviest sin upon your bed of sickness;
'Twill cost your soul the deepest groan it fetches;
And in that hope I leave you.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Farewell wagtail.
Marry thee quoth 'a! That's wise work indeed!
If we should marry every wench we lie with,
'T were after six a week with some of us.
(Marry love forbid) when two is enough to hang one.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Nat, we have sought diligently, for fear
The news that is abroad should fly before us.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: What news? What flying fame do you labour with?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: News that makes all the gallants i'the town
Fly out o'their little wits: they are so eager,
Upon the joy. I mean such youthful gallants
As have, or sold, or mortgaged; or been cheated
by the grave patron of arch-cozenage,
Whose sad misfortune we are come to sing:
Shall I need to name him to thee?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Who, the old rascal quicksands? speak good Vince,
What! has he hanged himself? speak quickly prithee.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Worse, worse by half man. Dared thou hear a news
Whose mirth will hazard cracking of a rib?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Ay, an't be two. Here's hoops enough besides
To hold my drink in. Pray thee speak; what mischief
Is come upon him.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I pray thee guess again.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Has somebody overreached him in his way
Of damnable extortion; and he cut his throat,
Or swallowed poison?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Ten times worse than that too.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Is he then hoist into the star-chamber
For his notorious practises? or into
The high commission for his blacker arts?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Worse than all this.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Pax, keep it to yourself then,
If you can think it be too good for me.
Why did you set me a longing? you cry worse
And ten times worse; and know as well as I,
The worse it is to him, the better welcome
Ever to me: and yet you tell me nothing.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: He has married a young wife.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Has he cadzooks?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: We bring you no comfort, we.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Ne'er go fine sport, ha, ha, ha. What is she?
Would he had my wench, was here e'en now,
What is she he has married? quickly prithee.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: One much too good for him.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: The beauteous Millicent.
Driven by the tempest of her uncle's will,
Is like a pinnace forced against the rock.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: But he will never split her, that's the best on't.
I hope she'll break his heart first. Gentlemen,
I thank you for your news; and know what I
Will presently go do.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Pray stay a little.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: And take us with you. What will you go do?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: That which we can all at once, do not hold me.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: We came to cast a plot w'ye.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Cast a pudding — how long ha' they been married?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: But this morning.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: You'll ha' me come too late.
Never go 'tis a shame he was not cuckolded
Before dinner.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: That had been a fine first course
At a wedding feast indeed. A little patience.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Pray let me take my course 'fore supper yet.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: The business belongs to us as much as you,
He has wronged us all alike. He has cozened us
As much as you.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: He has made me so poor
That my poor whore e'en now claimed marriage of me.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: The case is ours. His wrongs are common to us,
So shall his wife be, can we purchase her:
Did we bring you the news for you to run
And prevent us do you think?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Pardon my zeal good gentlemen; which only
Considered but the fitness of the act,
And that 'tis more than time 'twere done i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: And see here comes a fourth man that has lost
More on her part, than we upon the bridegrooms.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: He's very sour and sad. 'tis crept upon him
By this untoward accident.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: 'Twould anger any man to be nosed of such a match;
But I'll remove his sorrow —
Gentle Theophilus, you are well met,
Your sorrow is familiar with us all
In the large loss of your betrothed love;
but, sir, be comforted: you have our pity
And our revenge to ease you. 'tis decreed
Her husband shall be instantly a cuckold.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Most sinfully thou liest; and all that give
Breath to that foul opinion.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: What do you mean.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Give me that thought from you; nay, from you all,
Or I will rip you for't.

sp.speaker: Nat:
sp.l: Zooks what mean you.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Hold, sir, forbear.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I'll have that thought out first.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I say he does deserve to be a cuckold;
Let him be what he will, a pox upon him.

sp.speaker: Ed. Vin.
sp.l: So we say all.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What's that too ill in her?
I stand upon that point. Man's evil merit's
No warrant for a woman's dishonesty.
I say had she a man forty degrees
Beneath his undeservings, 'twere more possible
For him to deceive her with a good life,
Than she him with a wicked.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I say so too.
But then I say again, the more's the pity.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Do and undo.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Zooks now your bitch has bit me,
I say he will be one, he shall be one;
I'll make him one myself.
sp.stage: Ent. Ar. in his false beard he sides with Theoph. Ext. Na●. Vin. Ed.

sp.speaker: Ed. Vin.
sp.l: And we'll both help him.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Why here's trim stuff. Help ho, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: This is oppression gentlemen; an unmanly one.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: What devils this raised? fall off, 'tis an ill business.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Have you no hurt sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: No I'm confident.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: By your favour, I will see.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: What fortune's this,
I fought 'gainst friends to save mine enemy,
but I hope neither know me. I desire
To rest hid to my friends for my offence to them,
And to mine enemy, till I make him dearer.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I told thee there was none.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I'm glad it proves so.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: But where's the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Do you not know him sir?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Not I, 'tis the first time that ere I saw him;
To my remembrance; yet he fought for me.
Beshrew thy idler care that made me lose him,
What should he be that so could fight for me,
Yet care not for my company? beshrew thy heart.
Why should he use me thus? I shall be sick to think on't.
I'm made beholding now to I know not whom;
And I'm the worst to sue or seek to a man —

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: That scurvy, between proud and bashful quality,
You are famous for, as tother toy that haunts you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Why, to be deadly angry, sir,
On least occasion, and friends as quickly.
Hot and cold in a breath: you are angry now
With him that fought for you I warrant you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: In troth I am, and friends with them I fought with;
He used me peevishly to leave me so,
Ere I could thank him.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: So 'tis that I told you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: But did you mark th'humanity of my gentlemen,
Cause she's disposed by herself willed uncle
On that unworthy quick sands (Devil take him)
They thought 'twould sound like music in my ears
To hear her disgrace sung; when her fair honour
Is all I have to love, now she's took from me:
And that they'd go about to rob me of.
Heaven grant me patience. O my slaughtered father!
I am thy son, and know by thy infirmity.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Methinks , sir, his example should allay you:
impatience was his ruin.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Push, we see
Thieves daily hanged for robberies; yet some
Go on still in the practice! What a fine
Is set upon the head of foul adultery,
And yet our neighbours wives can hardly scape us!
There's laws against extortion, and sad penalties
Set upon bribes,
Yet great men's hands ha' their forefather's itch!
Prisons are filled with bankrupts; yet we see
How crafty merchants often wrong their credits,
And Londoners fly to live at Amsterdam!
Nothing can banish nature: that's the moral.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: It was indeed your fathers known infirmity,
And ever incident to the noblest natures.
But of your father, is there yet no hope
Of better news?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: No, certainly he's slain.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I have not heard a story of more wonder;
That two such men, of such estates and years,
Having lived always friends and neighbours nearly,
Should at the last fall out so mortally
On a poor cast at bowls! Where waste they sought?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: It is uncertain. All we heard of 'em
Was, they road forth ('tis now a whole year passed)
Singly to end their quarrel: but to what
Part of the kingdom, or the world they took,
We can by no inquiry find or hear
Of either of them. Sure they crossed the seas,
And both are slain.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You speak poor comfort sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I speak as my heart finds. She's gone for ever too;
Her hearts desire be with her.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Now he's there again.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Then my poor sister's sickness; that torments me,
Never in health since our dear father left us.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: And now there.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: How shall I do to see these men again?
I shall not be at rest till I be friends with 'em.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Why here's the noble nature still. 'twil show itself.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I'll seek 'em out. Nathaniel always loved me.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Here's an unsettled humour. In these fits
He'll ne'er be mad, nor ever well in's wits.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Go to I say, go to; as you're my niece,
And hope t'inherit any thing that's mine:
Shake off this maiden peevishness. Do you whimper
Upon your wedding day? Or, do you think
You are not married yet? Did you not say
I Millicent take Mandevill? A ha!
Was it not so? Did not I give you too?
I that have bred you from the cradle up
To a fit growth to match with his fair years;
And far more fair estate.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Ay, there's the match —

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Love him I charge you.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I'll endeavour't sir.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: You will endeavour't! Is't no further yet?
Stand from her, nephew! I'll so swinge her. Ha!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Let me entreat your patience. She's my wife sir.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Dandle her in her humour, do; and spoil her.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: 'Tis but her modesty.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Her sullen doggedness,
I'll baste it out of her. You do not know her
As I do, nephew.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: I shall, sir, before morning
Better I doubt not. Come we shall agree.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: You will endeavour't! Come I'll see it done.
Marry a man first, and then endeavour
To love him will you? Ha! is it but so?
I'll see you love him presently. So to bed.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: What before supper?

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: A posset and to bed,
I'll see it done. And cause you are so nice
(To bed I say) there I will see more done
Then I will speak. Tell me of your endeavour!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Be not so rough and stiff with her, good uncle,
I know my supple tender dealing will
Get more upon her love then all your chidings.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Such tender dealers spoil young brides; and get
Nothing of stubborness. Down with her I say
Now in her wedding sheets: she will be naught else.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Construe more charitably, I beseech you,
My virgin blushes.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: 'Tis your sullenness;
Would you have bribed it so lumpishly
With your spruce younker, that fine silken beggar,
Whose land lies in your husband's counting house;
Or the most part.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: O my Theophilus.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Indeed the better half; not without hope
To have the rest as he may want my money.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Would you have whined and pulled, had you had him,
To bedward think you? yet to speak the truth,
And that wherein she has vexed me a thousand times,
I never saw her laugh, nor heard her sing
In all my life: yet she could both, I have heard,
In company she liked.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: It has been 'mong maidens then.
But honoured sir (I know what I will do)
To let you see and hear, since you desire
To have me show a cheerfulness unto
My reverend husband: look you sir, I'll kiss him,
Clap him, and stroke him: ha, my Joe, ha, ha, ha, etc.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Hey day.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: She'll make me blush anon I think.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I'll sing him songs too.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Whoop, how's this?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: That I will chick, old songs and over old ones,
Old as thy reverend self, my chick a bird.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: She calls me chick and bird: the common names
With wives that cuckold their old craven husbands.

quote.l: She made him a bed of the thistle down soft,
She laid herself under to bear him a loft,
And ever she sung sweet turn thee to me,
We'll make the new bed cry jiggy joggy.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: What impudence is this.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: She's gone as far
Beyond it now as it was to't.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Now may you answer.

quote.l: Go to bed sweet heart I'll come to thee,
Make thy bed fine and soft I'll lig with thee. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Is this your bashful niece.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: What canst thou mean by this? dos this become thee?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Pray do not beat me o'my wedding might, but tell me
How this and half a dozen chopping children may
Become an old man's wife some five years hence.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: O intolerable!

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Is't possible thou canst do thus?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Let women judge. 'tis very possible
That a young lusty wife may have six children
By one at once in five years, sir, and by
One father too. I'll make him young enough
To father mine.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: She'll make a youth of me.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: There was a lady loved a swine.
And wilt thou be true love mine.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Do you hear gentlewoman; are you i' your wits?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Yes, and my own house I hope. I pray be civil.
Shall we to bed, sir, supperless? you need
No stirring meats, it seems. I'm glad on't.
Come, Biddy, come away, will you see uncle
How I will love him ●oed? come away.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: My edge is taken off. this impudence
Of hers, has outfaced my concupiscence.
Dashed all quite out of countenance! what a beast
Was I to marry? Rather, what a beast
Am I to be? * how now! O horrible.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: What hideous noise is this.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: I cannot help it.
While I went forth for the half pint of sack
To make your prodigal posset; and the maid
(Watching the milk, for running o'er) forgot
To shut the door, they all rushed in.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: What they, what all?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Vizarded people, sir, and oddly shaped.
You'll see anon. Their tuning o'their pipes,
And swear they'll gi' ye a willy-nilly dance
Before you go to bed, tho' you stole your marriage.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Outrageous roisters.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Call and raise the street.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: That were to let in violence indeed.
These are some merry harmless friends I warrant.
I knew I could not be so ill beloved
Among the bachelors, but some would find
Way to congratulate our honoured marriage.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: What, with horn music?

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: A new kind of flourish.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: 'Tis a flat conspiracy.
This is your bashful modest whimpering niece.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Then let 'em in. If they wrong us tonight ,
The law tomorrow shall afford us right.
Pray let's resolve to see't. Here comes their prologue.

sp.speaker: Mer
sp.l: At a late parliament held by the gods,
Cupid and Hymen fell at bitter odds
Upon an argument; wherein each did try
T'advance his own above tother's deity,
Out of this question, which might happier prove
Love without marriage, or marriage without love.
By the effects the trial must be made:
So each from others office drew his aid;
Cupid no more of Hymen's matches framed;
Nor Hymen married those that love inflamed.
Now mark, the sad effects this strife begotten,
Cupid his fiery darts and arrows shot
As thick as ere he did; and equal hearts
He wounds with equal love. But Hymen parts
Their forward hands (Alas!) and joineth none
But those which his new match-maker brings on,
(Old greedy avarice) who by his spells,
In breasts of parents and of guardians dwells,
That force their tenderlings to loathed beds;
Which uncouth policy to sorrow leads
Thousands a thousand ways, of which the least
Is this with which we celebrate your feast.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: A special drove of horn beasts.
sp.stage: Enter four masquers with horns on their heads: a stag, a ram, and Goat, an ox followed by four persons, a courtier, a captain, a scholar and a butcher.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: These few are thought enough to show how more
Would appear horrible, the town hath store.
The first's a lawyer, who by strife prevailed
To wed a wife, that was by love entailed
Unto that courtier, who had the hap
Soon after to adorn him with that cap.
The next a country Cormorant, whose great wealth,
by a bad father's will, obtained by stealth
That valiant soldier's mistress: for which matter
The Engineer his sconce with rams did batter.
This an old goatish usure, that must
Needs buy a wretch's daughter to his lust;
Doted, and married her without a groat,
That herald gave this crest unto his coat.
And that's the citizen, so broadly pated,
Which this mad butcher, cuckold antedated.
Now by this dance let husband that doth wed
Bride from her proper love to loathed bed
Observe his fortune. Music strike aloud
The cuckold's joy, with merry pipe and crowd.
sp.stage: They dance to music of cornets and violins.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: How now! all vanished! The devil take the hindmost.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: The foremost I say; and lay him a block
For all the rest to break their necks upon.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Who are they? Can you guess.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Truly, not I sir.
Some of my husband's friends perhaps, that came
To warn him of his fortune.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Well considered.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Lock the doors after 'em, and let us to bed;
And lock ourselves up, chick, safe from all danger.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: We will to bed chick, since you'll have it so.
This key shall be your guard: and here's another
Shall secure me. My house has store of beds in't.
I bring you not to an unfurnished dwelling.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Be not afraid to lie with me, good man,
I'll so restore thee 'Gain with caudles and cock-broths,
So cuckle thee up tomorrow, thou shalt see —

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: O immodesty.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Thou hast good store of gold, and shalt not want it
In cullises: in every broth I'll boil
an angel at the least.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I'll hang first.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: I am quite out of wits; and yet I'll counsel
Thee, nephew. Hark thee.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: 'Tis like to be mad counsel.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: But will you not lie with me then?

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: No marry shall he not.
Nephew, you shall not, till she bride it modestly.
'Tis now too late, but I'll so rattle her up tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: 'Tis too late now, and yet he'll do't tomorrow! good!

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Will you to your lodging?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Where be my bridemaids?

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: They wait you in your chamber.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: The devil o'maid's i' but my fellow Madge the kitchen maid, and malkin the cat, or bachelor but myself, and an old fox, that my master has kept a prenticeship to palliate his palsy.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Where be the maids, I say; and bachelors
To disappoint my husband.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Mark you that?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I mean, to take your points. But you have none.
O thrifty age! My bridegroom is so wise,
In stead of points, to hazard hooks and eyes.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: She means the eyes in's head, I'll hang else.
My master is like to make a blind match here.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Take up the lights, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I hope she talks so idly, but for want
Of sleep; and sleep she shall for me tonight .

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: And well said nephew. Will you to your chamber, mistress? —

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Hey ho, to bed, to bed, to bed.
No bride so glad — to keep her maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You're the first maid that ere I entertained
Upon so small acquaintance. Yet you're welcome,
I like your hand and carriage.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: 'Tis your favour.
But love, they say sweet mistress, is received
At the first sight, and why not service then,
Which often brings more absolute returns
Of the dear trust imposed, and firmer faith
By servants then by lovers?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Stay there Phillis.
I may, by that, conjecture you have been
Deceived by some false lover.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Who, I mistress?
I hope I look too merrily for such a one,
Somewhat too coarsely too, to be beloved;
If I were sad and handsome, than it might
Be thought I were a little love sick. Pray
How long has this disease affected you;
This melancholy, mistress? Not ever since
You lost your father I hope.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: For the most part.
Thou saidst, methought , that love might be ta'en in
At the first fight

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: There 'tis. I find her.
Love, mistress? yes, a maid may take in more
Love at one look, or at a little loophole,
Than all the doddy poles in town can purge
Out of her while she lives; she smothering it,
And not make known her passion. There's the mischief ▪

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Suppose she love an enemy to her house.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: An enemy! Put case the case were yours.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: But 'tis no case of mine; put by I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I'll put it to you though I miss your case.
Suppose it were your house, and master Arthur,
Whose father was your father's enemy,
Were your beloved —

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Pray thee no more.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Now I have struck the vein. Suppose I say,
All this were true; would you confound yourself
In smothering your love, which, in itself,
Is pure and innocent, until it grow
To a pernicious disease within you;
And hide it in your bosom, till it work
Your kindled heart to ashes?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Thou hast won
My patience to attention: therefore tell me
If thou canst find or think it honourable
In me to take such an affection?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes, and religious; most commendable,
Could you but win his love into a marriage,
To beget peace between your families.
How many, and what great examples have we,
From former ages, and of later times,
Of strong dissensions between furious factions,
That to their opposite houses have drawn in
Either's allies and friends, whole provinces,
Yea, kingdoms into deadly opposition;
Till the wide wounds on both sides have sent forth
Rivers of blood, which only have been stopped
By the soft bands of love in marriages
Of equal branches, sprung from the first roots
Of all those hellbred hatreds!

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My good maid —

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes, I have been a good one to my grief.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Thou hast given me strength to tell thee, and I hope
When it is told, I shall have yet more ease.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I warrant you mistress. Therefore out with it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I love that worthy gentleman; and am confident
That in the time of our two fathers' friendship
He 'Affected me no less: but since that time
I have not seen him, nor dare mention him
To wrong my brother's patience, who is so passionate,
That could he but suspect I bred a thought
That favoured him, I were for ever lost.
For this sad cause, as well as for the loss
Of my dear father, I have sighed away
Twelve moons in silent sorrow; and have heard
That Arthur too (But for what cause I know not)
Has not been seen abroad; but spends his time
In pensive solitude.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Perhaps he grieves
As much for the supposed loss of you,
As of his father too.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: The best construction,
I make of his retiredness, is the blessed
Prevention (Which I daily pray for) of
A fatal meeting 'twixt him and my brother,
Which would be sure the death of one or both.
And now that fear invades me, as it does always,
My brother being abroad; and such an absence
Has not been usual: I have not seen him
Since yesterday —

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Fear nothing, mistress. Now you have eased your mind,
Let me alone to comfort you. And see your brother.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: How is it with you sister?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Much better now then when you left me brother,
If no ill accident has happened you
Since your departure; as I fear there has:
Why look you else so sadly? speak, dear brother.
I hope you did not meet the man you hate.
If you did, speak. If you have fought and slain him,
I charge you tell, that I may know the worst
Of fortune can befall me: I shall gain
perhaps a death by't.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You speak as if you loved the man I hate,
And that you fear I have killed him.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Not for love
Of him I assure you sir; but of yourself.
Her fear in this case, sir, is that the law
May take from her the comfort of her life
In taking you from her, and so she were
But a dead woman. We were speaking
Of such a danger just as you came in;
And truly, sir, my heart even tremble-tremble-trembles,
To think upon it yet. Pray, sir, resolve her.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Then 'twas your frivolous fear that wrought in her.
Good sister be at peace: for, by my love to you,
(An oath I will not violate) I neither saw
Nor sought him, I. But other thoughts perplex me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What, were you at the wedding, brother?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Whose wedding, sister?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Your lost love Millicent's. Are you now sad
After your last leave taking?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: There may be other matches, my good brother —

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You wrong me shamefully, to think that I
Can think of other than her memory.
Though she be lost and dead to me, can you
Be so unnatural as to desire
The separation of a thought of mine
From her dear memory; which is all the comfort
My heart is married to, or I can live by.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Surely good sir, in my opinion,
Sharp, eager stomachs may be better fed
With airy smell of meat, than the bare thought
Of the most curious dainties —

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What piece of impudence have you received
Into my house?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Pray brother pardon me.
I took her, as I find her, for my comfort,
She has by council and discourse wrought much
Ease and delight into my troubled thoughts.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Good maid forgive me; and my gentle sister,
I pray thee bear with my distractions.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: A good natured gentleman for all his hasty flashes.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And now I'll tell you sister (Do not chide me)
I have a new affliction.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What is it brother?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am engaged unto a gentleman,
(A noble valiant gentleman) for my life,
By hazarding his own, in my behalf.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: It was then against Arthur.
What villain was't durst take your cause in hand
Against that man?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You wrong me beyond sufferance,
And my dear father's blood within yourself,
In seeming careful of that man's safety —

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: His safety sir? Alas! she means, he is
A villain that would take the honour of
His death out of your hands, if he must fall
By sword of man.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Again, I ask you pardon. But I had
A quarrel yesterday, that drew strong odds
Upon my single person; three to one:
When, at the instant, that brave gentleman
With his sword, sides me, puts 'em all to flight —

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: But how can that afflict you?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: How quick you are!

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Good brother I ha'done.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: My affliction is,
That I not know the man, to whom I am
So much engaged, to give him thanks at least.
O sir you're welcome, though we parted somewhat
Abruptly yesterday.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Pray thee nat. tell me, for I hope thou knowest him;
What gentleman was that came in betwixt us?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: If the devil know him no better, he will lose
A part of his due I think. But to the purpose,
I knew your wonted nature would be friends
With me before I could come at you. However, I
Have news for you that might deserve your love,
Were you my deadly enemy.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What is't pray thee?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Sweet mistress Lucy so long unsaluted?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My brother attends your news sir.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: My wench become her chambermaid! very pretty!
How the jade mumps for fear I should discover her.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Your news good nat? what is it ready made,
Or are you now but coining it?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: No, it was coined last night, o'the right stamp,
And passes current for your good. Now know,
That I, and Mun, and Vince, with divers others
Of our comrades, were last night at the bridehouse.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What mischief did you there?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: A masque, a masque lad, in which we presented
The miseries of enforced marriages
So lively — zooks, lay by your captious countenance,
And hear me handsomely.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Good brother do, it has a fine beginning.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: But mark what follows;
This morning, early up we got again,
And with our fiddlers made a fresh assault
And battery 'gainst the bedrid bridegrooms window,
With an old song, a very wondrous old one,
Of all the cares, vexations, fears and torments,
That a decrepit, nasty, rotten husband
Meets in a youthful, beauteous, sprightly wife:
So as the weak wretch will shortly be afraid,
That his own feebler shadow makes him cuckold.
Our masque o'er night begat a separation
Betwixt 'em before bed time: for we found
Him at one window, coughing and spitting at us;
She at another, laughing, and throwing money
Down to the fiddlers, while her uncle testy,
From a third porthole raves, denouncing law,
And thundering statutes'gainst their minstrelsy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Would he refuse his bridebed the first night?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Hang him.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Our horn-masque put him off it, (Bless my invention)
For which, I think, you'll judge she'll forsake him
All nights and days hereafter. Here's a blessing
Prepared now for you, if you have grace to follow it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Out of my house, that I may kill thee; go:
For here it were inhospitable. Hence,
Thou busy villain, that with sugard malice
Hast poisoned all my hopes; ruined my comforts
In that sweet soul for ever. Go, I say,
That I may with the safety of my manhood,
Right me upon that mischievous head of thine.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Is this your way of thanks for courtesies;
Or is't our luck always to meet good friends,
And never part so? yet before I go,
I will demand your reason (If you have any)
Wherein our friendly care can prejudice you;
Or poison any hopes of yours in Millicent?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Pray brother tell him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Yes: that he may die
Satisfied, that I did but justice on him,
In killing him. That villain, old in mischief,
(Hell take him) that has married her, conceives
It was my plot (I know he does) and, for
A sure revenge, will either work her death
By poison, or some other cruelty,
Or keep her locked up in such misery,
that I shall never see her more.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I answer —

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Not in a word, let me entreat you, go.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Fair mistress Lucy —

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Neither shall she hear you.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Her maid shall then: or I'll not out tonight .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: On what acquaintance sir.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Be not afraid: I take no notice o'thee,
I like thy course, wench, and will keep thy council,
And come sometimes, and bring thee a bit and th'wilt.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I'll see you choked first.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Thou art not the first
Cast wench that has made a good chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O you are base, and I could claw your eyes out.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Pray tell your master now: so fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I thank you, brother, that you promise me
You will not follow him now, some other time
Will be more fit. What said he to you, Phillis?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Marry he said (Help me good apron strings.)

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What was it that he said?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I have it now.
It was in answer, sir, of your objections.
First, that you feared the old man, wickedly,
Would make away his wife: to which he says,
That is not to be feared, while she has so
Much fear of heaven before her eyes. And next,
That he would lock her up from sight of man:
To which he answers, she is so endued
With wit of woman, that were she locked up,
Or had locks hung upon her, locks upon locks;
Locks of prevention, or security:
Yet being a woman, she would have her will;
And break those locks as easily as her wedlock.
Lastly, for your access unto her sight;
If you have land he says to sell or mortgage,
He'll undertake his doors, his wife and all,
shall fly wide open to you,

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: He could not lay so.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Troth, but 'tis like his wild way of expression.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes; I knew that: my wit else had been puzzled.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And now I find myself instructed by him;
And friends with him again. Now, Arnold, any tidings.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Not of the gentleman that sought for you. Ent. Arn.
But I have other news that's worth your knowledge.
Your enemy, young Arthur, that has not
Been seen abroad this twelvemonth is got forth
In a disguise I hear, and weaponed well.
I have it from most sure intelligence.
Look to yourself, sir.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My blood chills again.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Pseugh, I'll not think of him. To dinner sister.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Here was a good night, and good morrow to
Given by a crew of devils.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: 'Twas her plot,
And let her smart for't.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Smart, sir, did you say?
I think 'twas smart enough for a young bride
To be made lie alone, and gnaw the sheets
Upon her wedding.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Rare impudence!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: But for your satisfaction, as I hope
To gain your favour as you are my uncle,
I know not any actor in this business.
sp.stage: Ent. Buz. with a paper. Quick reads it.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Sir, here's a letter thrown into the entry.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: It is some villainous libel than I warrant.
Sawest thou not who conveyed it in?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Not 1. I only found it, sr.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Pray read it you. Not my own house free from 'em!
The devil owed me a spite; and when he has ploughed
An old man's lust up, he sits grinning at him.
Nay, I that have so many gallant enemies
On fire, to do me mischief, or disgrace;
That I must provide tinder for their sparks!
The very thought bears weight enough to sink me.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: May I be worthy, sir, to know your trouble?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Do you know yourself?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Am I your trouble then?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: 'Tis sworn and written in that letter there
Thou shalt be wicked. Hundreds have ta'en oaths
To make thee false, and me a horned monster.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: And does that trouble you?

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Does it not you?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: A dream has done much more. Pray, sir, your patience,
And now I will be serious, and endeavour
To mend your faith in me. Is't in their power
To destroy virtue, think you; or do you
Suppose me false already; 'tis perhaps
Their plot to drive you into that opinion.
And so to make you cast me out amongst 'em:
You may do so upon the words of strangers;
And if they tell you all, your gold is counterfeit,
Throw that out after me.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Now she speaks woman.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: But since these men pretend, and you suppose 'em
To be my friends, that carry this presumption
Over my will, I'll take charge of myself,
And do fair justice, both on them and you:
My honour is my own; and I'm no more
Yours yet, on whom my uncle has bestowed me,
Than all the worlds (The ceremony off)
And will remain so, free from them and you;
Who, by the false light of their wildfire flashes
Have slighted and depraved me and your bride bed;
till you recant your wilful ignorance,
And they their petulant folly.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: This sounds well.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Both they and you trench on my peace and honour;
Dearer than beauty, pleasure wealth and fortune;
I would stand under the fall of my estate
Most cheerfully, and sing: for there be ways
To raise up fortune's ruins, were her towers
Shattered in pieces, and the glorious ball
She stands on cleft asunder: but for peace
Once ruined, there's no reparation;
If honour fall, which is the soul of life,
'Tis like the damned, it ne'er lifts the head
Up to the light again.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Niece, thou hast won me;
And nephew, she's too good for you. I charge you
Give her her will: I'll have her home again else.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I know not what I can deny her now.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I ask but this, that you will give me leave
To keep a vow I made, which was last night
Because you slighted me.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Stay there a little.
I'll lay the price of twenty maidenheads
Now, as the market goes, you get not hers
This seven-night.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: My vow is for a month; and for so long
I crave your faithful promise not to attempt me.
In the mean time because I will be quit
With my trim, forward gentlemen, and secure you
From their assaults; let it be given out,
That you have sent me down into the country
Or back unto my uncles; whither you please.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Or, tarry, tarry — stay, stay here a while.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: So I intend, sir, I'll not leave your house,
But be locked up in some convenient room
Not to be seen by any, but yourself ▪
or else to have the liberty of your house
In some disguise, (If it were possible)
Free from the least suspicion of your servants.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: What needs all this?
Do we not live in a well governed city?
And have not I authority? I'll take
The care and guard of you and of your house
'Gainst all outrageous attempts; and clap
Those goatish roarers up, fast as they come.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: I understand her drift, sir, and applaud
Her quaint device. 'twill put 'em to more trouble,
And more expense in doubtful search of her,
The best way to undo 'em is to foil 'em
At their own weapons. 'tis not to be thought
They'll seek, by violence to force her from me,
But wit; in which we'll overcome 'em.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Agree on't twixt yourselves. I see you're friends.
I'll leave you to yourselves.
Hark hither niece — now I dare trust you with him:
He is in years, 'tis true. But hearest thou girl
Old foxes are best blades.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I'm sure they stink most.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Good keeping makes him bright and young again.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: But for how long.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: A year or two perhaps.
Then, when he dies, his wealth makes thee a countess.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You speak much comfort, sir.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: That's my good girl.
And nephew, love her, I find she deserves it;
Be as benevolent to her as you can;
Show your good will at least. You do not know
How the good will of an old man may work
In a young wife. I must now take my journey
Down to my country house. At your month's end
I'll visit you again. No ceremony
Joy and content be with you.

sp.speaker: Quic. Mil.
sp.l: And a good journey to you.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: You are content you say to be locked up
Or put in some disguise, and have it said
You're gone unto your uncles. I have heard
Of some bridegrooms, that shortly after marriage
Have gone to see their uncles, seldom brides.
I have thought of another course.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Be't any way.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: What if it were given out you're run away
Out of a detestation of your match?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: 'T would pull a blot upon my reputation.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: When they consider my unworthiness
'T will give it credit. They'll commend you for it.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You speak well for yourself.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: I speak as they'll speak.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Well; let it be so then: I am content.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: We'll put this instantly in act. The rest,
As for disguise, or privacy in my house,
You'll leave to me.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: All, sir, to your dispose,
Provided still you urge not to infringe
My vow concerning my virginity.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: 'Tis the least thing I think on,
I will not offer at it till your time.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Why here's a happiness in a husband now

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Thou tellest me things, that truth never came near.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: 'Tis perfect truth: you may believe it. Lady.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Maintained but in one syllable more, I'll tear
Thy mischievous tongue out.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Fit reward for tell-truths.
But that's not the reward you promised me
for watching of your brother's actions;
You said forsooth (If't please you to remember)
That you would love me for it.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Arrogant rascal.
I bade thee bring account of what he did
Against his enemy; and thou reportest.
He took his enemy's danger on himself,
And helped to rescue him whose bloody father
Killed ours. Can truth or common reason claim
A part in this report? My brother do't!
Or draw a sword to help Theophilus.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: 'Tis not for any spite I owe my master,
But for my itch at her that I do this.
I am strangely taken. Such brave spirited women
Have cherished strong backed serving-men ere now.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Why dost not get thee from my sight, false fellow?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I'll be believed first. Therefore prey have patience
To peruse that.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: My brother's character!
Theophilus sister's name — the brighter Lucy
So often written? nothing but her name —
But change of attributes — one serves not twice.
Blessed, divine, illustrious, all perfection;
And (So heaven bless me) powerful in one place.
The worst thing I read yet, heap of all virtues —
Bright shining, and all these ascribed to Lucy.
O I could curse thee now for being so just
Would thou hadst belied him still.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I ne'er belied him, I.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: O mischief of affection! Monstrous! horrid.
It shall not pass so quietly. Nay stay.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: She'll cut my throat I fear.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Thou art a faithful servant.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: It may do yet:
To you I am sweet lady, and to my master
In true construction: he is his friend I think
that finds his follies out to have them cured,
Which you have only the true spirit to do.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: How I do love thee now!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: And your love mistress,
(Brave sprightly mistress) is the steeple top
Or rather Weathercock o'top of that
To which aspires my life's ambition.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: How didst thou get this paper.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Amongst many
Of his rare twelvemonths melancholy works,
That lie in's study. Mistress 'tis apparent
His melancholy all this while has been
More for her love, then for his father's death.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Thou hast my love for ever.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Some small token
In earnest of it. Mistress, would be felt,
sp.stage: He offers to kiss her, she strikes him.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Take that in earnest then.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: It is a sure one.
And the most feeling pledge she could have given:
For she is a virago. And I have read
That your virago's use to strike all those
They mean to lie with: and from thence 'tis taken
That your brave active women are called strikers.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Set me that chair.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: The warm touch of my flesh
Already works in her. I shall be set
To better work immediately. I am prevented.
A way and be not seen. Be sure I love thee.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: A ha! This clinches. Another time I'm, sure on't.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Sister! where are you? How now! not well or

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Sick brother — sick at heart, o — (Sleepy.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Passion of heart! where are our servants now
To run for doctors? ho —

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Pray stay and hear me.
Here's no work for them. They'll find a master here
Too powerful for the strength of all their knowledge.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What at thy heart?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Yes, brother, at my heart.
Too scornful to be dispossessed by them.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What may that proud grief be? good sister name it.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: It grieves me more to name it, than to suffer't.
Since I have endured the worst on't, and proved constant
To sufferance and silence, 'twere a weakness
Now to betray a sorrow, by a name,
More fit to be severely felt then known.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Indeed I'll know it.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Rather let me die,
Then so afflict your understanding, sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: It shall not afflict me.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I know you'll chide me for't.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Indeed you wrong me now. Can I chide you?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: If you be true and honest you must do't,
And heartily.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You tax me nearly there.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: And that's the physic must help me or nothing:

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: With grief I go about to cure a grief then.
Now speak it boldly, sister.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Noble physician — it is —

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: It is! what is it? If you love me, speak.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: 'Tis — love and I beseech thee spare me not.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Alas dear sister, canst thou think that love
Deserves a chiding in a gentle breast?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Do you pity me already. O faint man
That tremblest but at opening of a wound!
What hope is there of thee to search and dress it?
But I am in thy hands, and forced to try thee.
I love — Theophilus —

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Theophilus, brother;
His son that slew our father. There's a love!
O more than time 'twere looked, for fear it festers.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: She has put me to't indeed. What must I do?
She has a violent spirit; so has he;
And though I wish most seriously the match,
Whereby to work mine own with his fair sister,
The danger yet, in the negotiation
May quite destroy my course; spoil all my hopes.
I'll therefore put her off on't if I can.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Can you be tender now?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What! to undo you?
I love you not so slightly. Pardon me.
A rough hand must be used: for here's a wound
Must not be gently touched; you perish then,
Under a brother's pity. Pray sit quiet;
For you must suffer all.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I'll strive to do it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: To love the son of him that slew your father!
To say it shows unlovingness of nature;
Forgetfulness in blood, were all but shallow
To the great depth of danger your fault stands in.
It rather justifies the act itself,
And commends that down to posterity
By your blood-cherishing embraces. Children,
Born of your body, will, instead of tears,
By your example, offer a thankful joy
To the sad memory of their grandsire's slaughter.
Quite contrary! How fearful 'tis to think on't!
What may the world say too? There goes a daughter,
Whose strange desire leaped from her father's ruin;
Death gave her to the bridegroom; and the marriage
Knit fast and cemented with blood. O sister —

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: O brother.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How! Well? And so quickly cured?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Dissembler; foul dissembler.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: This is plain.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Thou'st played with fire; and like a cunning fellow
Bit in thy pain o'purpose to deceive
Another's tender touch. I know thy heart weeps
for what't has spoke against. Thou that dar'st love
The daughter of that fiend that slew thy father,
And plead against thy cause! unfeeling man,
Can not thy own words melt thee? To that end
I wrought and raised 'em: 't was to win thy health,
That I was sick; I played thy disease to thee,
That thou mightst see the loathed complexion on't,
Far truer in another then ones self.
And, if thou canst, after all this, tread wickedly,
Thou art a rebel to all natural love,
And filial duty; dead to all just council:
And every word thou mockedst with vehemence
Will rise a wounded father in thy conscience,
To scourge thy judgement. There's thy saint crossed out,
And all thy memory with her. I'll ne'er trust
sp.stage: She tears and throws the paper to him.
sp.l: Revenge again with thee (So false is manhood)
But take it now into mine own powerfully,
And see what I can do with my life's hazard;
Your purpose shall ne'er thrive. There I'll make sure work.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How wise and cunning is a woman's malice;
I never was so cozened.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Out of my doors pernicious knave and harlot;
Avaunt I say.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Good master.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: Pray you worship.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: You have all the wages you are like to have.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Nay, I dare take your word for that: you'll keep
All moneys fast enough whose ere it be,
If you but gripe it once.

sp.speaker: Quic!
sp.l: I am undone,
And shamed for ever by your negligence,
Or malice rather: for how can it be
She could depart my house without your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: That cursed mistress that ever she came here!
If I know of her flight, sir, may these hands
Never be held up, but to curse you only,
If you cashier me thus: because you have lost
Your wife before she was well found, must we
Poor innocents be guilty?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: For my part,
Or ought I know she may as well be gone
Out o'the the chimney top as out o'door.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: The door must be your way; and find her out,
Or never find my door again. Be gone.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Mad. O, you are a cruel master.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: So, so, so.
These cries are laughter to me: ha, ha, ha.
I will be master of my invention once,
And now be bold to see how rich I am
In my concealed wealth. Come, precious mark
Of beauty and perfection, at which envy
And lust aim all their rankling poisonous arrows.
But I'll provide they ne'er shall touch thy blood.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: What, are your servants gone?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Turned, turned away
With blame enough for thy supposed escape:
Which they will rumor so to my disgrace
Abroad, that all my envious adversaries
Will, betwixt joy of my conceived misfortune
In thy dear loss, and their vain hopes to find thee,
Run frantic thorough the streets, while we at home
Sit safe, and laugh at their defeated malice.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: But now for my disguise.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Ay, that, that, that.
Be but so good and gentle to thyself,
To hear me and be ruled by me in that,
A Queen's felicity falls short of thine.
I'll make thee mistress of a mine of treasure,
Give me but peace the way that I desire it —

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Some horrible shape sure that he conjures so.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: That I may fool iniquity, and triumph
Over the lustful stallions of our time;
Bed-bounders, and leap-ladies (As they term 'em)
Mount-mistresses, diseases shackle 'em,
And spitals pick their bones.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Come to the point. What's the disguise, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: First know, my sweet, it was the quaint device
Of a Venetian merchant, which I learned
In my young factorship.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: That of the Moor?
The blackamoor you spoke of? Would you make
An negro of me.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: You have passed your word,
That if I urge not to infringe your vow
(For keeping this month your virginity)
You'll wear what shape I please. Now this shall both
Kill vain attempts in me, and guard you safe
From all that seek subversion of your honour.
I'll fear no powdered spirits to haunt my house,
Rose-footed fiends, or fumigated goblins
After this tincture's laid upon thy face,
'Twil cool their kidneys and allay their heats.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Bless me! you fright me, sir. Can jealousy
Creep into such a shape? Would you blot out
Heaven's workmanship?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Why think'st thou, fearful beauty,
Has heaven no part in Egypt? Pray thee tell me,
Is not an Ethiopes face his workmanship
As well as the fairest ladies? nay, more too.
Then hers, that daubs and makes adulterate beauty?
Some can be pleased to lie in oils and paste,
At sins appointment, which is thrice more wicked.
This (Which is sacred) is for sins prevention.
Illustrious persons, nay, even Queens themselves
Have, for the glory of a night's presentment,
To grace the work, suffered as much as this.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Enough sir, I am obedient.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Now I thank thee.
Be fearless love; this alters not thy beauty,
Though, for a time obscures it from our eyes.
Thou mayst be, while at pleasure, like the sun;
Thou dost but case thy splendour in a cloud,
To make the beam more precious in it shines.
In stormy troubled weather no sun's seen
Sometimes a month together: 'tis thy case now.
But let the roaring tempest once be over,
Shine out again and spare not.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: There's some comfort.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Take pleasure in the scent first; smell to't fearlessly,
And taste my care in that, how comfortable
'Tis to the nostril, and no foe to feature.
Now red and white those two united houses,
Whence beauty takes her fair name and descent,
Like peaceful sisters under one roof dwelling
For a small time; farewell. O let me kiss ye
Before I part with you — now jewels up
Into your ebon casket. And those eyes,
Those sparkling eyes, that send forth modest anger
To sing the hand of so unkind a painter,
And make me pull't away and spoil my work,
They will look straight like diamonds, set in lead,
That yet retain their virtue and their value.
What murder have I done upon a cheek there!
But there's no pitying: 'tis for peace and honour;
And pleasure must give way. Hold, take the tincture,
and perfect what's amiss now by your glass.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Some humbler habit must be thought on too.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Please your own fancy. Take my keys of all;
In my pawn wardrobe you shall find to fit you.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: And though I outwardly appear your drudge,
'Tis fit I have a maid for private service:
My breeding has not been to serve myself.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Trust to my care for that. One knock. In; in.
Is it to me your business?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yea, if you
Be master quicksands sir; the master's worship
Here o'the house.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: I am so. What's your business?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: 'Tis upon that, sir, I would speak sir, hoping
That you will pardon my presumptuousness,
I am a mother that do lack a service.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: You have said enough. I'll entertain no mothers.
A good maid servant, knew I where to find one.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: He is a knave, and like your worship, that
Dares say I am no maid; and for a servant
(It ill becomes poor folks to praise themselves,
But) I were held a tidy one at home.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: O thou'rt a Norfolk woman (Cry thee mercy)
Where maids are mothers, and mothers are maids.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I have friends i'th' city that will pass their words
For my good bearing.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Hast thou?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes indeed, sir.
I have a cousin that is a retorney
Of Lyons-inn, that will not see me wronged;
And an old aunt in Muggle-street, a midwife,
That knows what's what as well's another woman.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: But where about in Norfolk wert thou bred?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: At Thripperstown sir, near the city of Norwich.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: Where they live much by spinning with the rocks?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Thripping they call it, sir.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Dost thou not know one Hulverhead that keeps
An innocent in's house.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: There are but few innocents i'the country sr.
They are given too much to law for that: what should
That Hulverhead be a councillor, sir.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: No a husband man.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Truly I know none.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: I am glad she does not. How knew'st thou I wanted
A servant.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: At an old wife's house in Bowlane
That places servants, where a maid came in
You put away today.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: All, and what said she?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Truly to speak the best and worst, forsooth,
She said her fault deserved her punishment
For letting of her mistress run away.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: The news goes current. I am glad o'that.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And that you were a very strict hard man,
But very just in all your promises.
And such a master would I serve to choose.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: This innocent country mother takes me.
Her looks speak wholesomeness; and that old woman
That bow lane purveyor hath fitted me
With serviceable ware these dozen years.
I'll keep her at the least this gander month,
While my fair wife lies in of her black face,
And virgin vow; in hope she's for my turn.
Lust, when it is restrained, the more 'twill burn.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: May I make bold to crave your answer, sir?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Come in, I'll talk with you.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Prosper now my plot,
And hulk, thou art twixt wind and water shot.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You're welcome gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Let's ha' good wine, boy, that must be our welcome.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You shall, you shall sir.
Within. Ambrose, Ambrose;

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Here, here, anon, anon, by and by, I come, I come.
Jerom, Jerom, draw a quart of the best canary into the Apollo.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: This is a language that I have not heard.
You understand it, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: So shall you anon master buzzard.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Your friend and Jonathan buzzard kind gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: What excellent luck had we, friend buzzard, to
Meet with thee, just as thy master cast thee off.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Just sir, as I was going I know not whither:
And now I am arrived at just I know not where. 'tis a
Rich room, this. Is it not goldsmiths hall.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: It is a tavern man — and here comes the wine.
Fill boy — and here's to thee friend, a hearty draft to
Cheer thee — fill again boy — there, drink it off.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Off with it man — hang sorrow, cheer thy heart.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: And truly 'tis the best cheer that ere I tasted.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Come taste it better, here's another to thee.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: — And truly this was better than the first.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Then try a third. That may be best of all.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: — And truly, so it is — how many sorts of wine
May a vintner bring in one pot together?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: By Bacchus' Mr. buzzard, that's a subtle question.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Bacchus! who's that I pray?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: A great friend of the vintners, and master of their company indeed.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: I was never in all my life so far in a tavern before.
What comforts have I lost.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Now he begins to talk.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: Nor ever was in all my two and twenty years under that Babylonian tyrant quicksands , so far as a vintner's bar but thrice.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: But thrice in all that time?

sp.speaker: Buz.
