sp.p: Truly but thrice sir. And the first time was to fetch a jill of sack for my master, to make a friend of his drink, that joined with him in a purchase of sixteen thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Ay, there was thirst. More wine boy. A pottle and a beer bowl.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: The second time was for a penny pot of muscadine, which he drank all himself with an egg upon his wedding morning.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: And to much purpose, it seemed by his wives running away.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: The third and last time was for half a pint of sack upon his wedding night, of later memory; and I shall ne'er forget it, that riotous wedding night: when hell broke loose, and all the devils danced at our house, which made my master mad, whose raving made my mistress run away, whose running away was the cause of my turning away. O me, poor masterless wretch that I am. — oh —

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Hang thy master, here's a full bowl to his confusion.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: I thank you. Let it come sir, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Think no more of masters, friends are better than masters.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: And you are all my friends kind gentlemen, I found it before in your money when my master (Whose confusion I have drunk) took your mortgages; and now I find it in your wine. I thank you kind gentlemen still. O how I love kind gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: That shows thou art of gentle blood thyself, friend buzzard.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Yes friend — shall I call you friend?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: By all means, all of us.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p:
Why then, all friends, I am a gentleman, though spoilt i'the breeding. The buzzards are all gentlemen,
we came in with the conqueror. Our name (As the French has it) is Beau desert; which signifies — friends, what does it signify?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: It signifies, that you deserved fairly at your master's hands, like a gentleman, and a buzzard as you were, and he turned you away most beastly like a swine, as he is. And now here is a health to him, that first finds his wife, and sends her home with a bouncing boy in her belly for him to father.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. I'll pledge that: and then I'll tell you a secret.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Well said friend; up with that, and then out with thy secret.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: I will friend. And tother two friends, here's upon the same.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: I hope he will show us a way, out of the bottom of his bowl to find his mistress.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: This fellow was happily found.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: This was an excellent draught.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.p: But the secret, friend, out with that, you must keep no secrets amongst friends.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: It might prove a shrewd matter against my mischievous master as it may be handled.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Hang him cullion, that would turn thee away.
We'll help thee to handle it, fear it not.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hark you then all friends. Shall I out with it?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: What else.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: I'll first take tother cup, and then out with't altogether — and now it comes — if my mistress do bring him home a bastard, she's but even with him.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: He has one I warrant. Has he cadzooks?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: That he has by this most delicate drink. But it is the arsivarsiest aufe that ever crept into the world. Sure some goblin got it for him; or changed it in the nest, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I vow thou utterest brave things. Is't a boy?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: It has gone for a boy in short coats and long coats this seven and twenty years.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: An idiot is it.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: Yes: a very natural; and goes a thissen; and looks as old as I do too. And I think if my beard were off, I could be like him: I have taken great pains to practise his speech and action to make myself merry with him in the country.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Where is he kept, friend, where is he kept.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: In the further side of Norfolk, where you must never see him. 'tis now a dozen years since his father saw him, and then he compounded for a sum of money with an old man, one Hulverhead, to keep him for his life time; and he never to hear of him. But I saw him within these three months. We harken after him, as land-sick heirs do after their fathers, in hope to hear of his end at last.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: But hark you, friend, if your beard were off, could you be like him think you? What if you cut it off, and to him for a father.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Pray thee hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: My beard, friend, no: my beard's my honour.
Hair is an ornament of honour upon man or woman.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.p: Come, come; I know what we will do with him. Mun, knock him down with the other cup. We'll lay him to sleep; but yet watch and keep him betwixt hawk and buzzard as he is, till we make excellent sport with him.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hey ho. I am very sleepy.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: See he jokes already. Boy show us a private room.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: This way, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Down, Plumpton ▪ park, etc.
sp.stage: They lead Buz. out, and he sings.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Indeed you were unkind to turn away
My maid (Poor harmless maid) whose innocent mirth
Was the best cheer your house afforded me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am sorry sister, trust me, truly sorry,
And knew i which way to recover her
With my best care I would. Yet, give me leave,
I saw her overbold; and overheard her
Say, she foresaw that Arthur my sole enemy
Should be your husband. I'll marry you to death first.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Now you fly out again.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Your pardon again your sister,
And for your satisfaction I will strive
To oversway my passion. How now Arnold,
Methinks I read good news upon thy face.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The best, sir, I can tell is, the old Jew
Quicksands has lost his wife.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: She is not dead,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis not so well for him: for if she were
He then might overtake her though she were
Gone to the devil. But she's run away:
But to what corner of the earth, or under
Whose bed to find her is not to be thought.
It has raised such a laughter in the town
Among the gallants —!

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And do you laugh too?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes; and if you do not out-laugh all men
That hear the joyful news, 'tis too good for you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am too merciful, I kill thee not.
Out of my doors, thou villain, reprobate.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Hold, pray sir, hold.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Never while I have power to lift a hand
Against thee, mischievous villain.

sp.speaker: Lucy
sp.l: Is not this passion, brother?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Forbear, sister.
This is a cause turns patience into fury.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Arnold, forbear his sight.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And my house too.
Or villain, look to die, oft as I see thee.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Turned out o' doors! A dainty frantic humour
In a young master! Good enough for me though;
Because 'tis proper to old serving-men
To be so served. What course now must I take?
I am too old to seek out a new master.
I will not beg, because I'll cross the proverb
That runs upon old serving creatures; stealing
I have no mind to: 'tis a hanging matter.
Wit and invention help me with some shift
To help a cast-off now at a dead lift.
Sweet fortune hear my suit.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Why how now, Arnold! What, at thy devotion?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I'll tell you in your ear, sir, I dare trust you.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.l: Could earthly man have dreamt this rascal
Whose lechery, to all our thinking, was
Nothing but greedy avarice and cozenage,
Could have been all this while a concealed whoremaster,
To have a bastard of so many years
Nursled i'th' country?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Note the punishments
That haunt the miscreant for his black misdeeds;
That his base offspring proves a natural idiot;
Next that his wife, by whom he might had comfort
In progeny, though of some others getting,
Should with her light heels make him heavy-headed
By running of her country! And lastly that
The blinded wretch should cast his servant off,
Who was the cover of his villainy,
to show us (That can have no mercy on him)
The way to plague him.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha —

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: What dost laugh at?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: To think how nimble the poor uzzard is
To be revenged on's master; how he has shaped himself;
Cut off his beard, and practised all the postures
To act the changeling bastard.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Could we light
Upon some quaint old fellow now, could match him
To play the clown that brings him up to town,
Our company were full, and we were ready
To put our project into present action.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Gentlemen, we are fitted: take this man w'ye
He is the only man I would have sought,
To give our project life. I'll trust thee Arnold,
And trust thou me, thou shalt get pieces by't;
Besides, I'll piece thee to thy master again.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: That clinches sir.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Go follow your directions.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Come away then.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Sweet mirth thou art my mistress. I could serve thee.
And shake the thought off of all woman kind
But that old wonts are hardly left. A man
That's entered in his youth, and thoroughly salted
In documents of women, hardly leaves
While reins or brains will last him: 'tis my case.
Yet mirth, when women fail, brings sweet encounters
That tickle up a man above their sphere:
They dull, but mirth revives a man: who's here,
The solitary musing man, called Arthur,
Possessed with serious vanity; mirth to me!
The world is full: I cannot peep my head forth
But I meet mirth in every corner: ha!
Sure some old runt with a splay-foot has crossed him!
Hold up thy head man; what dost seek? thy grave?
I would scarce trust you with a piece of earth
you would choose to lie in though; if some plump mistress
Or a deft lass were set before your search.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How vainly this man talks!

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Gid ye good den forsooth.
How vainly this man talks! speak but truth now,
Does not thy thought now run upon a wench?
I never looked so but mine stood that way.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis all your glory that; and to make boast
Of the variety that serves your lust:
Yet not to know what woman you love best.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Not I cadzooks, but all alike to me,
Since I put off my wench I kept at livery:
But of their use I think I have had my share,
And have loved every one best of living women;
A dead one I ne'er coveted, that's my comfort:
But of all ages that are pressable;
From sixteen unto sixty; and of all complexions
From the white flaxen to the tawny-moor;
And of all statures between dwarf and giants;
Of all conditions, from the doxy to the Dowsabel.
Of all opinions, I will not say religious:
(For what make they with any?) and of all
Features and shapes, from the huckle-backed bum-creeper,
To the straight spiny shop-maid in st. Martin's.
Briefly, all sorts and sizes I have tasted.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: And thinkst thou hast done well in't!

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: As well as I could with the worst of 'em though i say't.
Few men come after me that mend my work.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: But thou never thinkst of punishments to come;
Thou dreamest not of diseases, poverty,
The loss of sense or member, or the cross
(Common to such loose livers) an ill marriage;
A hell on earth to scourge thy conscience.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Yes, when I marry, let me have a wife
To have no mercy on me; let the fate
Of a stale doubting bachelor fall upon me;
let me have quicksands curse, to take a wife
Will run away next day, and prostitute
Herself to all the world before her husband.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Nay, that will be too good: if I foresee
Any thing in thy marriage destiny,
'Twil be to take a thing that has been common
To th'world before, and live with thee perforce
To thy perpetual torment.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Close that point.
I cannot marry. Will you be merry, Arthur?
I have such things to tell thee.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Pray thee come closer to me. What has crossed thee?
Is thy supposed slain father come again,
To dispossess thee for another life time?
Or has thy valiant sister beaten thee? Tell me.
It shall go no further.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Let your valiant wit
And jocund humour be supposed no warrant
For you t'abuse your friends by.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Why didst tell me of marrying then? But I
Have done. And now pray speak what troubles you.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I care not if I do: for 'twill be town talk.
My sister on a private discontent
Betwixt herself and me hath left my house.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Gone quite away?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes, and I know not whither.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Beyond sea sure to sight with th'air, that took
Her father's last breath into't. Went she alone?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No, no; my man's gone with her.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Who, the fellow
That brags on's back so; the stiff strong chined rascal?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Even he.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: The devil is in these young tits,
And wildfire in their cruppers.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Let me charm you,
by all our friendship, you nor speak nor hear
An ill construction of her act in this,
I know her thoughts are noble; and my woe
Is swollen unto that fullness, that th' addition
But of word in scorn would blow me up
Into a cloud of wild distempered fury
Over the heads of all whose looser breath
Dare raise a wind to break me. Then I fall
A sudden storm of ruin on you all.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I know not how to laugh at this: it comes
So near my pity. But I'll to my grigs
Again; and there will find new mirth to stretch
And laugh, like tickled wenches, hand o'er head.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: How does my habit and my arms become me?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Too well to be a woman, manly mistress.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Where's the pistol you provided for me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Here mistress and a good one.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: 'Tis too long.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: No lady would wish a shorter. If it were
'T would bear no charge, or carry nothing hotne.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I'll try what I can do. Thou think'st me valiant.
I'm sure I have often felt it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: All the viragoes that are found in story,
Penthesilea and Symaramis
Were no such handy strikers as yourself:
But they had another stroke, could you but find it,
Than you were excellent. I could teach it you.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I dare not understand thee yet. Be sure
As you respect my honour, or your life
That you continue constant to my trust,
And so thou canst not know how much I'll love thee.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: There is a hope as good, now, as a promise.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Here at this inn abide, and wait my coming
Be careful of my guildings: be not seen
Abroad for fear my brother may surprise you.
There's money for you; and ere that be spent
'Tis like I shall return.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Best stars attend you,
Mars arm thee all the day; and Venus light
Thee home into these amorous arms at night.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Be cheered my love; help to bear up the joy,
That I conceive by thy concealed beauty,
Thy rich imprisoned beauty, whose enfranchisement
Is now at hand, and shall shine forth again
In its admired glory. I am rapt
Above the sphere of common joy and wonder
In the effects of this our quaint complot.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: In the mean time, though you take pleasure in't,
My name has dear suffered.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: But thine honour
Shall, in the vindication of thy name,
When envy and detraction are struck dumb
Gain an eternal memory with virtue;
When the discountenanced wits of all my jeerers
Shall hang their heads, and fall like leaves in autumn.
O how I laugh to hear the cozened people
As I pass on the streets abuse themselves
By idle questions and false reports.
As thus: good morrow master quicksands; pray
How fares your beauteous bedfellow? says another
I hear she's not at home. A third says no:
He saw her yesterday at the still-yard
with such a gallant, sousing their dried tongues
In Rhenish, deal, and back-rag: then a fourth
Says he knows all her haunts and meetings
At Bridgfoot, bear, the tons, the cats, the squirrels;
Where, when, and in what company to find her,
But that he scorns to do poor me the favour:
Because a light piece is too good for me.
While a fifth youth with counterfeit show of pity,
Meets, and bewails my case, and says he knows
A lord that must be nameless keeps my wife
In an enchanted castle two miles West
Upon the riverside : but all conclude —

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: That you are a monstrous cuckold, and deserve it.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Knowing my safety, then, and their foul errors,
Have I not cause to laugh? Yes, in abundance.
Now note my plot, the height of my invention
I have already given out to some,
That I have certain knowledge you are dead,
And have had private burial in the country;
At which my shame, not grief, forbade my presence:
Yet some way to make known unto the world
A husband's duty, I resolve to make
A certain kind of feast, which shall advance
My joy above the reach of spite or chance.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: May I partake, sir, of your rich conceit?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Tomorrow night expires your limited month
Of vowed virginity; it shall be such a night;
In which I mean thy beauty shall break forth
And dazzle with amazement even to death
Those my malicious enemies, that rejoiced
In thy supposed escape, and my vexation.
I will invite 'em all to such a feast
As shall fetch blushes from the boldest guest;
I have the first course ready —

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: And if I
Fail in the second, blame my housewifery.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Away, somebody comes; I guess of them
That have jeered me, whom I must jeer again.
Gallants you're welcome. I was sending for ye.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: To give us that we come for?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: What may that be?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Trifles you have of ours.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Of yours, my masters?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Yes, you have in mortgage
Threescore pound land of mine inheritance.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: And my annuity of a hundred marks.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: And jewels, watches, plate, and clothes of mine,
Pawned for four hundred pound. Will you restore all?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: You know all these were forfeited long since,
Yet I'll come roundly to you, gentlemen.
Ha'you brought my moneys, and my interest?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: No surely. But we'll come as roundly to you
As moneyless gentlemen can. You know
Good offices are ready money sir.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: But have you offices to sell, good sirs.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: We mean to do you offices worth your money.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: As how, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Marry, sir, as thus;
We'll help you to a man that has a friend —

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: That knows a party, that can go to the house —

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Where a gentleman dwelled, that knew a scholar

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: That was exceeding well acquainted with a traveler

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.l: That made report of a great magician beyond the seas.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: That might ha' been as likely as any man in all the world.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: To have helped you to your wife again.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: You are the merriest mates that ere I coped withal.
But to be serious gentlemen, I am satisfied
Concerning my lost wife. She has made even
With me and all the world.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: What is she dead?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Dead, dead: and therefore as men use to mourn
for kind and loving wives, and call their friends
Their choicest friends unto a solemn banquet
Served out with sighs and sadness, while the widowers
Blubber, and bathe in tears (Which they do seem
To wring out of their fingers ends and noses)
And after all the demure ceremony.
Are subject to be thought dissemblers, I
(To avoid the scandal of hypocrisy,
Because 'tis plain she loved me not) invite
You and your like that loved her and not me,
To see me in the pride of my rejoicings,
You shall find entertainment worth your company,
And that let me entreat tomorrow night.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: You shall ha' mine.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Tomorrow night say you.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Yes gallants: fail not, as you wish to view
Your mortgages and pawns again. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: We came to jeer the Jew, and he jeers us.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: How glad the rascal is for his wife's death.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: An honest man could not have had such luck.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: He has some further end in't, could we guess it,
Than a mere merriment for his dead wife's riddance.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Perhaps he has got a new wife, and intends
To make a funeral and a marriage feast
In one to hedge in charges.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: He'll be hanged rather than marry again.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Zooks would he had some devilish jealous hilding,
'Twould be a rare addition to his mirth,
For us to bring our antic in betwixt 'em
Of his changeling bastard.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Howe'er we'll grace his feast with our presentment.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: When's the buzzard?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: We left him with his foster father, Arnold,
Busy at rehearsal practising their parts.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: They shall be perfect by tomorrow night.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: If not unto our profit, our delight.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Brother be comforted.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Let not the name
Or empty sound of comfort mix with th'air
That must invade these ears: they are not capable,
Or, if they be, they dare not, for themselves,
Give the conveyance of a syllable
Into my heart, that speak not grief or sorrow.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Be grieved then, I'll grieve with you: for each sigh
You waste for Millicent's untimely death
I'll spend a tear for your as fruitless sorrow.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: That's most unsuitable; you're no company
For me to grieve with if you grieve for me;
Take the same cause with me; you are no friend
Or sister else of mine. It is enough
To set the world a weeping!

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: So it is;
All but the stony part of't.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Now you are right. Her husband's of that part;
He cannot weep by nature: but I'll find
A way by art in chemistry to melt him.
At least extract some drops. But do you weep
Indeed for Millicent? What, all these tears?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: All for your love.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: She is my love indeed; and was my wife.
But for the empty name of marriage only,
But now she's yours for ever. You enjoy her.
In her fair blessed memory; in her goodness,
And all that has prepared her way for glory.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Let me embrace thee sister. How I reverence
Any fair honour that is done to her,
now thou shalt weep no more: thou hast given me comfort
In showing me how she's mine. And tears indeed
Are all too weak a sacrifice for her
But such as the heart weeps.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Sit down brother.
Sing boy the mournful song I bade you practise.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Call you this mournful. 'tis a wanton air.
Go you're a naughty child indeed, I'll whip you
If you give voice unto such notes,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I know not brother how you like the air,
But in my mind the words are sad, pray read 'em.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They are sad indeed ▪ how now my boy, dost weep?
I am not angry now.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I do not weep,
Sir, for myself. But there's a youth without
(A handsome youth) whose sorrow works in me:
He says he wants a service, and seeks yours.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Dost thou not know him ▪

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: No: but I pity him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: O, good boy, that canst weep for a stranger's misery!
The sweetness of thy dear compassion
Even melts me too. What does he say he is.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: 'Tis that sir, that will grieve you when you hear it.
He is a poor kinsman to the gentlewoman
Lately deceased that you so loved and mourn for.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And dost thou let him stay without so long?
Merciless villain! run and fetch him quickly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: O brother —

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Sister, can I be too zealous
In such a cause as this? For hark you, sister,

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: There was no way like this to get within 'em,
Now courage keep true touch with me. I'll vex
Your cunning and unnatural purpose, brother,
if I do nothing else.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Sir, here's the youth?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: A lovely one he is, and wondrous like her,
Oh let me run and clasp him; hang about him,
And yoke him to me with a thousand kisses!
I shall be troublesome and heavy to thee,
With the pleased weight of my incessant love.
Youth of a happy kindred, which foreruns
A happy fortune ever. Pray thee, sister,
Is he not very like her?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: If I durst
I would now say, this were the better beauty,
For it resembles Arthur's.

sp.speaker: The,
sp.l: Is't not her face? you do not mind me sister:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Hers was a good one once, and this is now.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Why sister, you were wont to take delight
In any comfort that belonged to me;
And help to carry my joys sweetly: now
You keep no constant course with me.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: This man
Melts me — alas, sir, I am a poor boy.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What, and allied to her? impossible!
Where ere thou livest her name's a fortune to thee.
Her memory amongst good men sets thee up;
It is a word that commands all in this house.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: This snare was not well laid. I fear myself.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Live my companion; my especial sweet one,
My brother and my bedfellow thou shalt be.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: By lakin but I must not, though I find
But weak matter against it. — this my courage!

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: She took from earth, how kind is heaven, how good
To send me yet, a joy so near in blood!
Good noble youth, if there be any more
Distressed of you, that claims alliance with her
Though afar off; deal freely; let me know it,
Give me their sad names; I'll seek 'em out,
and like a good great man, in memory humble
Ne'er cease until I plant 'em all in fortunes,
And see 'em grow about me.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I hear of none, myself excepted, sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Thou shalt have all my care then, all my love.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: What make I here? I shall undo myself.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Yet note him sister.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I there's the mark my malice chiefly aims at;
But then, he stands so near, I wound him too.
I feel that must not be. Art must be shown here.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Come, you shall kiss him for me, and bid him welcome.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You are most welcome, sir, and were her name
To which you are allied, a stranger here,
Yet, sir, believe me, you in those fair eyes
Bring your own welcome with you.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Never came malice among so sweet a people.
It knows not how to look, nor I on them.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Let not your gentle modesty make you seem
Ungentle to us, by turning so away.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: That's well said sister, but he will and shall
Be bolder with us, ere we part.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I shall too much I fear. —

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Come gentle blessing,
Let not a misery be thought on here,
(If ever any were so rude to touch thee)
Between us we'll divide the comfort of thee.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I have heard thy story often, and with pity
As often thought upon't, and that the father,
of my best loved Theophilus, together with
His, then, friend master Meanwell (Who have since
Become each others deathsman as 'tis thought)
By suits in law wrought the sad overthrow
Of thy poor father's fortune; by which means,
Poor gentleman he was enforced to leave
His native country to seek foreign means
To maintain life.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Or rather to meet death.
For since his travail, which is now six years,
I never heard of him.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Much pitiful!

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: So is your story, mistress unto me.
But let us dry our eyes; and know we must not
Stick in the mire of pity; but with labour
Work our delivery: yours is now at hand
If you set will and brain to't. But my honour
(If a poor wench may speak so) is so cracked
Within the ring, as 'twill be hardly soldered
By any art. If on that wicked fellow,
That struck me into such a desperate hazard.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: He will be here tonight , and all the crew
And this must be the night of my delivery,
I am prevented else for ever, wench.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Be sure, among the guests, that you make choice
Of the most civil one to be your convoy,
And then let me alone to act your Moors part.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Peace, he comes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I'll to my shift then.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Where's my hidden beauty?
That shall this night be glorious.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I but wait the good hour
For my deliverance out of this obscurity.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: 'Tis at hand.
So are my guests. See some of 'em are entered.
Oh my blithe friend, master Nathaniel, welcome.
And master Arthur Meanwell as I take it.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Yes, sir, a gentleman late possessed with sadness,
Whom I had much ado to draw along
To be partaker more of your mirth then cheer.
You say here shall be mirth. How now, what's that?
Ha' you a black coney berry in your house?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Stay Catelina. Nay, she may be seen.
For know, sirs, I am mortified to beauty
Since my wife's death. I will not keep a face
Better than this under my roof I ha' sworn.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You were too rash, sir, in that oath, if I
May be allowed to speak.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: 'Tis done and passed, sir.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: If I be not taken with yond funeral face,
And her two eyes the scutcheons, would I were whipped now.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Suppose your friends should wish you to a match
Prosperous in wealth and honour.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: I'll hear of none, nor you if you speak so.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Sir, I ha'done.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: It is the handsom'st rogue
I have ere seen yet of a deed of darkness;
Tawny and russet faces I have dealt with,
But never came so deep in blackness yet.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Come hither Catelyna. You shall see, sir,
What a brave wench she shall be made anon
And when she dances how you shall admire her.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Will you have dancing here tonight .

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Yes I have borrowed other Moors of merchants
That trade in Barbary, whence I had mine own here,
And you shall see their way and skill in dancing.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: He keeps this rye-loaf for his own white white tooth
With confidence none will cheat him of a bit;
I'll have a sliver though I lose my whittle.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Here take this key, 'twill lead thee to those ornaments
That decked thy mistress lately. Use her casket,
And with the sparklingst of her jewels shine;
Flame like a midnight beacon with that face,
or a pitched ship a fire; the streamers glowing
And the keel mourning, (How I shall rejoice
At these preposterous splendours) get thee glorious;
Be like a running firework in my house.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: He sets me more a fire at her. Well old stick breech
If I do chance to clap your Barbary buttock
In all her bravery, and get a snatch
In an odd corner, or the dark tonight
To mend your cheer, and you hereafter hear on't,
Say there are as good stomachs as your own,
Hist, negro, hist.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: No fee, oh no, I darea notta.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Why, why — pish — pox I love thee,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: O no de fine white Zentilmanna
Cannot a love a the black a thing a.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Cadzooks the best of all wench.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: O take — a heed — a my mastra see — a.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: When we are alone, then wilt thou.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Then I shall speak a more a.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: And I'll not lose the Moor-a for more than I
Will speak-a.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: I muse the rest of my invited gallants
Come not away.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Zooks the old angry justice.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: How comes it sir, to pass, that such a news
Is spread about the town? is my niece dead,
And you prepared to mirth sir, hah?
Is this the entertainment I must find
To welcome me to town?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: She is not dead, sir. But take you no notice
You shall have instantly an entertainment, that
Shall fill you all with wonder.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Sure he is mad;
Or do you understand his meaning sirs?
Or how or where his wife died?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I know nothing;
but give me leave to fear, by his wild humour,
He's guilty of her death; therefore I hope
He'll hang himself anon before us all
To raise the mirth he speaks of.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Fie upon you.
Yet trust me, sir, there have been large constructions,
And strong presumptions, that the ill made match
Betwixt her youthful beauty and his covetous age;
Between her sweetness and his frowardness
Was the unhappy means of her destruction;
And you that gave strength to that ill tied knot
Do suffer sharply in the world's opinion,
While she, sweet virgin, has its general pity.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Pray what have you been to her? I ne'er found you
Appear a suitor to her.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: I ne'er saw her,
Nor ever should have sought her, sir; for she
Was only love to my sworn enemy,
On whom yet (Were she living and in my gift
Rather a thousand times I would bestow her
Then on that man that had, and could not know her.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: I have done ill; and wish I could redeem
This act with half my estate.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: This devil's bird,
This Moor runs more and more still in my mind.
O are you come? And ha'you brought your scene
Of mirth along with you?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Yes, and our actors
Are here at hand: but we perceive much business
First to be set a foot. Here's revels towards.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: A dance of furies or of blackamoors
Is practising within;

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: But first there is to be some odd collation
In stead of supper.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Cheap enough I warrant,
But saw you not a moorhen there amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: A pretty little rogue, most richly decked
with pearls, chains and jewels. She is Queen
Of the night's triumph.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: If you chance to spy me
Take her aside, say nothing.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Thou wilt filch
Some of her jewels perhaps.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I'll draw a lot
For the best jewel she wears. But mum my masters.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Enter the house pray gentlemen: I am ready
Now with your entertainment.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: We'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Now for six penny custards, a pipkin of baked
Pears, three saucers of stewed prunes, a groat's worth
Of strong ale, and two pennyworth of gingerbread.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: If she does live (As he bears me in hand
She is not dead) I'll tell you briefly, sir,
If all the law bodily and ghostly,
And all the conscience too, that I can purchase
With all the wealth I have can take her from him,
I will recover her, and then bestow her
(If you refuse her) on your so you speak of,
(Whose right she is indeed) rather than he
Shall hold her longer. Now mine eyes are opened.
Will you walk in.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I pray excuse me, sir,
sp.stage: Exit, enter Mili. white. faced and in her own habit.
sp.l: I cannot fit myself to mirth.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Your pleasure.
Mil. Have I with patience waited for this hour,
And does fear check me now? I'll break through all,
And trust myself with yond mild gentleman.
He cannot but be noble.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: A goodly creature!
The rooms illumined with her; yet her look
Sad, and cheek pale, as if a sorrow sucked it.
How came she in? What is she? I am fear ▪ struck.
'Tis some unresting shadow. Or, if not,
what makes a thing so glorious in this house,
The master being an enemy to beauty?
She modestly makes to me.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Noble sir, —

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Speaks too.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: If ever you durst own a goodness,
Now crown it by an act of honour and mercy.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Speak quickly; lose no time then: say, what are you?
You look like one that should not be delayed.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I am th'unfortunate woman of this house,
To all men's thoughts at rest. This is the face
On which the hell of jealousy abused
The hand of heaven, to fright the world withal.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Were you the seeming Moor was here?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: The same;
And only to your secrecy and pity
I have ventured to appear myself again.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What's to be done? Pray speak, and 'tis performed.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: In trust and manhood sir, I would commit
A great charge to you, even my life and honour
To free me from this den of misery.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: A blessed task! But when you are freed lady —

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I would desire sir, than to be conveyed. —

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Whither? to whom? speak quickly: why do you stoop?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Pray let that rest. I will relieve your trouble
When I am freed from hence, and use some others.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Nay, that were cruelty. As you love goodness tell me.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Why dare you bear me sir, to one you hate.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: What's that, if you love? 'tis your peace I wait on.
I look upon your service, not mine own.
Were he the mortalest enemy flesh bred up
To you I must be noble.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You profess —

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: By all that's good and gracious, I will die
Ere I forsake you, and not set you safe
Within those walls you seek.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Then, as we pass
I'll tell you where they stand, sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You shall grace me.

div.head: Act 4. Scene 5.
div.stage: Quick sands. Testy. Nath. Vincent. Edmond.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Now to our revels. Sit ye, sit ye gallants
Whilst, uncle, you shall see how I'll requite
The mask they lent me on my wedding night.
'Twas but lent gentlemen, your mask of horns,
And all the private jeers and public scorns
You've cast upon me since. Now you shall see
How I'll return them; and remarried be.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I hope he'll marry his Moor to anger us.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I'll give her something with her, if I catch her,
An't be but in the coal-house.
sp.stage: Flourish enter inductor like a Moor leading Phillis (Black and) gorgeously decked with jewels.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Attend gentleman.

sp.speaker: Inductor
sp.l: The Queen of Aethiop dreamt upon a night
Her black womb should bring forth a virgin white.

sp.speaker: Inductor
sp.l: She told her King; he told thereof his peers.
Till this white dream filled their black heads with fears:

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: A whoreson blockheads.

sp.speaker: Inductor
sp.l: Blackheads I said. I'll come to you anon

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: He puts the blockheads on 'em grossly.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Brave impudent rogue. He made the speeches last year
Before my lord marquis of fleet conduit.

sp.speaker: Inductor
sp.l: Till this white dream filled their blackheads with fear,
For 'tis no better than a prodigy
To have white children in a black country.
So 'twas decreed that if the child proved white,
It should be made away. O cruel spite!
The Queen cried out, and was delivered
of child black as you see: yet wizards said
That if this damsel lived married to be
To a white man, she should be white as he.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: The moral is, if quicksands marry her,
Her face shall be white as his conscience.

sp.speaker: Inductor
sp.l: The careful Queen, conclusion for to try,
Sent her to merry England charily
(The fairest nation man yet ever saw)
To take a husband; such as I shall draw,
Being an Egyptian prophet.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Draw me, and I'll hang thee.

sp.speaker: Inductor
sp.l: Now I come to you, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Now mark my jeers.

sp.speaker: Inductor
sp.l: You must not have her: for I find by your hand
You have forfeited the mortgage of your land.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Pox o'your palmistry.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Now me.

sp.speaker: Inductor
sp.l: Nor you: for here I plainly see
You have sold and spent your life's annuity.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: The devil take him, made thee a soothsayer.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I find from whence your skill comes. Yet take me
For thy little Princess of darkness, and if
I rub her not as white as another can
Let me be hung up with her for a new
Sign of the labour in vain.

sp.speaker: Inductor
sp.l: Nor you, sir: for
The only suit you wear smells of the chest
That holds in limbo Lavender all your rest.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Would his brains were in thy belly that keeps the key on't.

sp.speaker: Inductor
sp.l: This is the worthy man, whose wealth and wit,
To make a white one, must the black mark hit.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Your jeers are answered, gallants. Now your dance.
sp.stage: Enter the rest of the Moors. They dance an antique in which they use action of mockery and derision to the three gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: We applaud your device, and you'll give me leave
To take your black bride here, forth in a dance.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: With all my heart, sir.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Music, play a galliard,
You know what you promised me, Bullis.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: But howa can ita be donea.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: How I am taken with the elevation of her nostrils.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Play a little quicker — hark you — if I lead you
A dance to a couch or a bed side, will you follow me?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I will doa my besta.
sp.stage: Nat. dances vily. Quicks. And Tes. laughs and looks off.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: So, so; quick music, quick.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: O ugly! call you this dancing; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Do you laugh at me.
sp.stage: Enter Arnold like a country man, and Buz. like a changeling, and as they enter, exit Nat. with Phil. the music still playing.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: By your leave gentlefolks.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: O brave, o brave.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: How now.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: What are these?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hack ye there, hack ye there,
Oh brave pipes. Hack ye there.
sp.stage: He sings and dances and spins with a rock and spindle.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle loodle loo.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: What are you men or devils?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You are advised enough: sir, if you please
But to be short, I'll show you I am a Norfolk man,
And my name is John Hulverhead.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You cannot hear o'chat side it seems.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I know thee not, not I.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: But you know my brother Matthew Hulverhead
deceased, with whom you placed this simple child of yours.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I placed no child in Norfolk nor Suffolk nor any
Folk I — say thou mistookst me: I'll reward thee. Go.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I cannot hear o'that ear neither, sir.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: What's the matter, Mr. quicksands?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Ha'you any more jeers to put upon us? what are these?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle loodle loo.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Get you out of my house.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I may not till I be righted. I come for right, and
I will have right, or the best of the city shall
Hear on't.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I swear the rascal's act it handsomely.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: What art thou fellow? What dost thou seek?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Tell that gentleman: he is an upright magistrate
And will see thee righted.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.p: I am a poor Norfolk man, sir. And I come to ease myself of a charge, by putting off a child natural to the natural father here.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: My child! Am I his father? Dar'st thou speak it.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Be not ashamed on't, sir: you are not the first grave and wise citizen that has got an idiot.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Here's good stuff towards.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha — with a hay toodle loodle loodle loo.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: How should I get him. I was never married till this month.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: How does other bawdy bachelors get children?

sp.speaker: Buz
sp.l: With a hay toodle loodle loodle loo, etc.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Have you been a bastard-getter and marry my niece.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Now it works.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: I'll teach you to get a bastard, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: He needs none o'your skill it seems.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle, etc.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Well, gentlemen, to take your wonder off,
I will lay truth before you.
For a poor servant that I had, I undertook and paid
For keeping of an idiot.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Who, your man buzzard?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Even he.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle, etc.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: 'Tis like this is the child. But for a certain sum
Which I did pay, 'twas articled, that I should ne'er be
Troubled with it more.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Now what say you to that sir?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: 'Tis not denied sir, there was such agreement,
But now he is another kind of charge.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Why, he gets something towards his living methinks .

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes, he has learned to thrip among the mothers;
But sir, withal, to do more harm than good by't,
And that's the charge I speak of: we are not bound
To keep your child, and your child's children too.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Sir, by his cunning at the rock,
And twirling of his spindle on the thrip-skins,
He has fetched up the bellies of sixteen
Of his thrip-sisters.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle, loodle, loodle, etc.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Is't possible.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: So well he takes after his father here it seems.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Take heed o'that friend: you heard him say it was his man's child.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: He sha'not fright me with that, though it be
A great man's part to turn over his bastards
To his servants. I am none of his hirelings, nor
His tenants I. But I know what I say; and I know
What I come about; and not without advise; and you
May know, that Norfolk is not without as knavish
Council, as another county may be. Let his man Buz.
Be brought forth, and see what he will say to't.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle, etc.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Wretch that I was to put away that fellow!
But stay! where is my wife? my wife, my wife —

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: What say you, sir?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: My Moor I would say. Which way went my Moor?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Your Ethiopian Princess.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Is gone to dance with her in private, because you laughed him out of countenance here.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Mischief on mischief! worse and worse I fear.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: What do you fear, why stare you? Are you frantic?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I must have wits and fits, my fancies and fegaries.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Your jeers upon poor gallants.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: How do you feel yourself.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle, etc.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Ask your father blessing Timsy.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle, etc.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Upon your knees man.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Upon all my knees. A — ah. Hay toodle loodle.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: What was't to you, you slaves?
sp.stage: Enter Nat. and Phillis pulled in by the Moors.
sp.l: Must you be peeping.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: What was't to you, ye rascals?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: It is to us sir, we were hired to dance and to speak speeches; and to do the gentleman true service in his house: and we will not see his house made a bawdy house, and make no speech o'that.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: What is the business?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: Marry sir a naughty business. This gentleman has committed a deed of darkness with your Moor, sir; we all saw it.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: What deed of darkness? speak it plainly.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Darkness or lightness; call it which you will.
They have lyen together; made this same a bawdy house;
How will you have it?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Undone, most wretched. O, I am confounded.
I see no art can keep a woman honest.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I love her, and will justify my act.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And I the best of any man on earth.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Thou speakest good English now.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: O ruin, ruin, ruin —

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle, etc.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Why take you on so, for an ugly fiend?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: She is my wife, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How sir, your wife.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: In conceit you mean.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I say my lawful wife; your niece; and so disguised
By me on purpose.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: I said he was mad before, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Now I applaud my act, 'twas sweet and brave.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I'll be divorced before a court in public.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Now will I use authority and skill.
Friends, guard the doors. None shall depart the house.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Mun. Vin. Content, content.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Shall I, sir, and my charge stay too?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: O —

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Marry sir, shall you.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: I fear we shall be smoked then.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: No, no, fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: You know your chamber housewife. I'll wait o'your master
Tonight . We will not part until tomorrow day,
Justice and law lights every one his way.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Is this your merry night, sir?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: O — o — o — oh —

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Why roar you so?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: It is the cuckold's howl. A common cry about the city.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: O oh — buz. Hay toodle loodle, etc.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: Now my good host, since you have been our friend
and only council keeper in our absence,
To you, before we visit our own houses
We'll render a relation of our journey,
And what the motive was that drew us forth.
'Tis true, we did pretend a deadly quarrel
At a great bowling match upon black-heath;
Went off; took horse; and several ways, forecast
To meet at Dover, where we met good friends,
And in one bark passed over into France:
Here 'twas supposed to fight, like fashion followers
That thither fly, as if no sand but theirs
Could dry up English blood.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Now, by the way,
Suppose that supposition had been true,
And the supposed deaths of you, and you
Had moved your sons to combat in earnest,
And both been killed indeed, as you in jest,
Where had been then your witty subtlety,
My noble Meanwell, and my brave rashly?
Ha! have i twight ye there?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Thou keepest thy humour still my running host.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: My humour was, nor is, nor must be lost:
But, to the question, was it wisely done,
When each of you might so have lost a son?

lg.l: We had no fear of that sir, by the rule,
The common rule o'th' world. Where do you find
Sons that have lives and lands, will venture both
For their dead fathers that are gone and cared for?
Nor was it only to make trial of
What husbands they would be; how spend, or save;
How manage, or destroy; how one or both
Might play the tyrants over their poor tenants,
Yet fall by prodigality into th'compters:
And then the dead by pulling off a beard,
After a little chiding and some whining,
to set the living on their legs again,
And take 'em into favour; pish, old play-plots.
No sir, our business runs another course;

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Nor yet, nor yet;
Best wits may have bad memories; I forget.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: It is my part to speak. Mine host, you've known me,
My name is Winloss; a poor gentleman,
Yet richer, by my liberty, than I was
For six years space, till these good gentlemen
In charity redeemed me.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Master Winloss!
I thought I could as soon forgotten my chriss-cross,
Yet (Pardon me) you have been six years gone,
And all of them in prison saving one,
In Dunkerk as I ween.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: It is most true;
And that from thence these gentlemen redeemed me
At their own charge, by paying five hundred pound,
Which was my ransom.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: 'Tis a rare example.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Worthy brass tables, and a pen of steel.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: No more good neighbour Winloss. What we did
Was to discharge our conscience of a burden
Got (And 'twas all we got) by your undoing,
In a sad suit at law.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I do remember;
And, without ruin I'll tell you, that sad cause,
In which you joined against him, overthrew him
And all his family: but this worthy act
Of yours in his enlargement, crowns your piety,
And puts him in a way of better fortune,
Than his first tottering estate could promise.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Shut up that point. You have heard no ill, you say,
Among our sons and daughters in our absence.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Not any sir at all. But, Mr. Winloss,
you that have passed so many sorrows, can
(I make no doubt) here one with manly patience.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: 'Tis of my daughter Phillis! Is she dead?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: 'Tis well and't be no worse with her: I fear
She's gone the tother way of all flesh, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Why dost thou tell him this?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: To have him right
His daughters wrong upon that wicked beast
That has seduced her.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Who is't? canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Even the rank-rider of the town, sir, one
Master Nathaniel Banelasse, if you know him.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: He has my son's acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: And mine's too.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: You may be proud on't, if they scape his doctrine.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: But does he keep my daughter to his lust?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: No, sir, 'tis worse than so. He has cast her off
To the common, as 'tis feared.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: O wretchedness!

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: How cam'st thou by this knowledge.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Sir, I'll tell you.
I have, i'th' house, a guest, was once your man,
And served your son, since you went o'er I'm sure on't,
Though now he has got a young spark to his master,
That has a brace of geldings in my stable;
And lusty ones they are. That's by the way.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: But to the point, I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Sir, the young gallant is abroad, the man
Scults close i'th' house here, and has done these two days
Spending his time with me in drink and talk.
Most of his talk runs upon wenches mainly;
And who loves who, and who keeps home, and so forth;
And he told me the tale that I tell you
Twixt Banelasse and your done and undone daughter.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Mine host — cry mercy gentlemen —

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: Nay, nay, come on.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I told you he was very shy to be seen.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My old master alive again? and he that he killed too?

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: Whom do you serve? was I so ill a master,
That, in my absence, you forsook my children?
Or how have they misused you? Why dost look
So like an apprehended thief? I fear
Thou servest some robber, or some murderer,
Or art become thyself one. If the devil
Have so possessed thee, strive to turn him out:
He add my prayers to help thee. What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: O honoured master! I'll keep nothing from you.
There is an act of horror now on foot,
Upon revenge of your supposed murder,
Of which to stand and tell the circumstance,
Would waste the time and hinder the prevention
Of your son's murder, and your daughter's ruin.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O fearful!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Let not your amazement drown
Your reason in delay; your sudden haste
Was never so required as now. Stay not
To ask my why, or whither. As ye go
I shall inform ye.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Go, we follow thee.

div.head: Act. 5. Scene 2.
div.stage: Dionysia as before in man's habit, sword and pistol.
div.l: What a fierce conflict twixt revenge and love,
Like an unnatural civil war, now rages
In my perplexed breast. There, fight it out;
To it pell-mell my thoughts. The battle's hot.
Now for the day! revenge begins to stagger,
And her distracted army at an instant
Routed and put to flight. All conquering love,
Thou hast got the victory; and now I sue
(Like a rent kingdom by self-opposite thoughts)
Unto thy sovereignty, to be the liege-right.
Take me to thy protection, kingly love,
And having captivated my revenge,
Oh, play not now the tyrant. A firm hope
Persuades me no: but when I shall
Reveal myself I shall obtain Theophilus' love.
Which now is ten times sweeter in my thought
Then my revenge was, when 'twas first begotten.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What, still alone? we have been seeking thee.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: O 'tis the service that I owe you sir.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Indeed you are too pensive: two whole days
And nights among us, and no more familiar?
sp.stage: Ent. Ar. in his false beard, leading in Mil. veiled. Pages they stand aloof.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: May I crave your name, sir?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: That's to little purpose,
My business is the thing — yonder's the star!
What young gentleman is that your mistress arm
Appears so courteous too?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: One she thinks well on sir,
No matter for his name, as you said, neither.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: He seems some well graced suitor. 'tis my fear,
If he should now — I must be just however.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Sir, a gentleman desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Dost thou not know his name?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: He will not tell it sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You treacherous boy, do you bring you know not whom?
O 'tis the gentleman I was so bound to, sister:
The welcomest man alive; thanks my good boy.
What's she he brings in veiled, and this way leads?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Sir, though I am still a stranger in my visit,
To works of gentleness, I am partly known.
There (If you chance t'enquire of me hereafter
(When I shall more deserve your inquisition)
I may be found, if not exact in service,
A least a poor pretender in my wishes:
And so presenting this white gift, (More modest
than the most secret duty of man's friendship
Can ever be) I take my leave —

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: This man
Would breed, at every time it's seen, a wonder!
Sir, leave me not thus lost: let me once know you,
And what this mystery means? This bears a shape
I may not entertain: I have set my vow
Against all woman kind, since heaven was married
To my first love; and must not willingly
Discover a temptation with mine own hand.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How shy and nice we are to meet our happiness!
Like dying wretches, 'fraid to go to rest.
Because you shall be guilty of no breach
I'll open the casket for you.
sp.stage: He unveils her, and slips away.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Bless me, it is —
Warm, so love cherish me and comfortable.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: O death, my hopes are blasted.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: How is it with you, sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Might a man credit his own senses now
This were my Millicent. How think you, sister?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Indeed I am so, my Theophilus.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: She lives, and he is lost to me for ever,
I shall be straight discovered too. False love
Thou hast dealt loosely with me; and revenge
I re-invoke thy nobler spirit: now
Possess me wholly; let it not be thought
I came and went off idly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Sir, something troubles you. See your kinswoman
My brother stands entranced too; brother, brother ▪
Noble lady, speak to him.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I was in my discovery too sudden.
Strong rapture of his joy transmutes him — sir,
Be not so wonder-struck; or, if you be,
Let me conjure you by the love you bore me,
Return unto yourself again. Let not
A wand'ring thought fly from you, to examine
from whence, or how I came: if I be welcome
I am your own and Millicent.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And in that
So blessed a treasure, that the wealth and strength
Of all the world shall never purchase from me.
Heaven may be pleased again to take thee, but
I'll hold so fast, that we'll go hand in hand;
Besides, I hope his mercy will not part us.
But where's the man now more desired then ever
That brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You ask in vain for him.
I can resolve you all; but for the present
He will be known to none.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: This is a cruel goodness: to put thankfulness
Out of all action. Sirrah, how went he?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I know not, sir, he vanished suddenly.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Vanished! good Lucy help to hold her fast
She may not vanish too. Spirits are subtle.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: This was my fear. Will you have patience,
And fit but in this chair while I relate my story.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I'll be as calm in my extremest deeps
As is the couch where a sweet conscience sleeps.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: 'Tis now determinate as fate; and so
At the whole cluster of 'em. Bless me ha'!
sp.stage: As Dionisia presents her pistol. Enter. Rash. Mean. Win. Rafe. Arthur.
sp.l: My father living! Then the cause is dead
Of my revenge.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: What is he killed out right.
Or else but hurt? Theophilus! my boy!
Dead, past recovery. Stay the murderess there.
Look you, sir, to her. I suspect your son too
Is not without a hand in't by the haste
We met him in.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: He is not hurt at all
My honoured father, as I desire your blessing,
But stricken with an ecstasy of joy.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Look up my boy. How dost? here's none but friends.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Sure, sure we're all then in Elysium
Where all are friends and filled with equal joy.
Earth can have no felicity like this.
If this be any thing.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Thou canst not see nothing,
Look well about thee man.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I see, I feel, I hear and know ye all:
But who knows what he knows, sees, feels, or hears?
'Tis not an age for man to know himself in.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: He is not mad I know by that.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: If I know any thing, you are my father —

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Thou art a wise child.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And I beseech your blessing.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Thou hast it. Millicent, I have heard your story,
And Lucy, you betwixt you soothe his fancy,
He will be well anon. Keep 'em company Arthur,
And Lucy, bid him welcome.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: More than life, sir.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: You Dionysia would be chid a little;
But, sir, let me entreat her pardon.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: Dry your eyes: you have it.
Go instantly resume your sex's habit,
And with the rest be ready, if we call ye
To Quicksands' house. The rumour of our coming
Already calls us thither to be assistant
To justice testy in a ponderous difference.

sp.speaker: Kash.
sp.l: How does he now?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: He's fallen into a slumber.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: In with him all I pray.

sp.speaker: Ar. etc.
sp.l: He shall have all our cares.
sp.stage: Exit with thee. in the chair.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Come my friend Meanwell. Now to quicksands cause,
To keep it out of wrangling lawyers jaws.
The face of danger is almost made clean
And may conclude all in a comic scene.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Come, we will hear this cause tried.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: See the judges
Have ta'en their seats, while we stand here for evidence.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: My worthy friends, you're come unto a cause
As rare, as was your unexpected coming
From the supposed grave —

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: To th' point I pray.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: How quick you are! Good Mr. rashly, know
(Though I craved your assistance) only I
Supply the chief place in authority.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: And much good do't you. I have other business —
Your niece sir was too good for my poor son.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: Nay gentlemen, we came to end
A business: pray begin no new one first.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Well sir, I ha'done.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: Pray sir fall to the question.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.l: Bring in the parties.
The first branch of the question rises here
If quicksands wife, my niece, be dead or living
Speak gentlemen. What can you say to this?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Quicksands affirmed to us, that she was dead.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Though, since in a distracted passion
He says she lives.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: She lives, and is that strumpet,
From whom I sue to be divorced.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: That Moor, there?
Did you wed her since your fair wife's decease?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: That same is she, and all the wives I had
that black is but an artificial tincture
Laid by my jealousy upon her face.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: This is most strange.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Braver and braver still,
I aimed but at a cloud and clasped a June,
Will you be only mine?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I have sworn it ever.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Then I am made for ever.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.l: Remove her, and let instant trial be made
To take the blackness off.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Then if her shame,
And my firm truth appear not, punish me.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: However, your consent to be divorced
From Millicent is irrecoverable.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Before you all, I'll forfeit my estate
If ere I re-accept her.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Then she's free.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Now Mr. Banelass —

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Now for the honour of wenchers.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Your fact is manifested and confessed.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: In fewest words it is.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Are you content
To take this woman now in question,
If she be found no Moor to be your wife,
In holy marriage to restore her honour?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Or else, before you all, let me be torn
To pieces; having first those dearest members,
In which I have most delighted, daubed with honey ▪

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: This protestation
Is clear, without respect of portion, now,
Or that she is my niece: for you must know
She is no niece of mine that could transgress
In that lean kind: nor must she ever look
For favour at my hands.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I am content, to take her as she is,
Not as your niece, but as his counterfeit servant,
hoping he'll give me with her all about her.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: My chains, and jewels, worth a thousand pounds,
I'll pay it for my folly.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: 'Twil be twice
The price of my pawned goods. I'll put the rest
Up for your jeers passed on my friends and me.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: You are agreed.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: To take her with all faults.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I take you at your word.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Ha —

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Hell and her changes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Lead by the hope of justice, I am bold
To fix here fast, here to repair my ruins.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: The devil looks ten times worse with a white face,
Give me it black again.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Are we not one, you know from the beginning?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Get thee from me.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Sirrah you have your suit and your desert,
'Tis your best part to pass it patiently.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: 'Tis Winloss daughter; we have found the error.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I am confounded here. Where is my wife?

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Ay, that's the point must now be urged. The law
Asks her at your hands. Answer me, where is she?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I am at my joys end, and my wits together.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: You have brought her fame in question: 'tis revenged
Now you are in both for her life and honour.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Speak villain, murderer, where is my niece?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I have snared myself exceeding cunningly;
That quean there knows.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Take heed, sir, what you say,
If she must be my wife. Hands off I pray,
These are my goods she wears. Give me 'em, Phil.
For fear he snatch, I'll put 'em in my pockets.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Sweet heart, my own will hold 'em.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Sweet heart already! we are soon familiar.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: You know we are no strangers.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Well Mr. quicksands: because you cannot answer
(To put you by the fear of halter-stretching)
Since you've engaged your word and whole estate
To be divorced: and you good Mr. testy,
If you'll be willing yet that my poor son
To wed your niece, as I shall find it lawful,
I'll undertake her safe recovery.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: I have in heart given her your son already.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: And he has her already.
sp.stage: Ent. The. Mil. Ar. Lu. Dio. Winloss.
sp.l: As for example, see sir.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: See, see, the heaven that I am justly fallen from,
Oh may I yet find favour.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Never here.
Hadst thou not given thy faith to a divorce,
On forfeiture of thine estate, which thou
Dost hold more precious; or couldst now redeem
That great engagement; and then multiply
Thy past estate into a tenfold sum.
Make me inheritrix of all; and last assure me
To die within a week, I'll not remarry thee:
Adulterate beast, that brokest thy former wedlock
In thy base lust with that thy servant there.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: What a pox no, I trow — my wife that must be?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: 'Twas your own doing, to put me to my shifts.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: The devil shift you, than you will be sure
Of change enough.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: O shame unto my blood.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I will henceforward council all my friends
To wed their whores at first, before they go
Out o'their hands.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: How can you answer this?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I utterly deny't upon my oath.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: So do I, and safely for any act.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: That's well again.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: It was but in attempt, I told my mistress,
Had it been done, sure I should ne'er have spoke on't.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Those are the counsels women can only keep.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Nothing in act I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: In him 'twas foul enough though.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: O hateful vice in age.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: 'Tis an old vice grown in him from his youth,
Of which bring forth for proof his bastard there.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: I fear we shall be whipped for counterfeits;
My long coats have a grudging of the lash.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I see my old master's face again, and I will
Fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Then I'll bear up again —
Hay diddy daddy , come play with the baby
Dindle dandle on thy knee, and give him a penny,
And a new coat, oh ho —

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: My grief and shame is endless.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Let not grief master you, Mr. quicksands.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: We are your friends, and pity your afflictions.
What will you give us now and we'll release you
For ever of this changeling charge of yours?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: And prove he's not your bastard. Speak now roundly.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I'll cancel both your mortgages.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: A match. Now look you sir, your quandam servant,
All but the beard he wore; for loss of which
We'll recompense him.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: O buzzard, buzzard, buzzard.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: O master, master, master. Your servant and no bastard,
Nor father of your idiot in Norfolk,
He's there, and well sir, I heard lately of him.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: How couldst thou use me thus?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: How could you turn me away so?

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. Come hither buzzard. Thou shalt not want a master.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Nor I, I hope, while my old master lives. You're welcome home sir.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: And thou to me my good old servant Arnold.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Well fare a misery of a man's own seeking;
a tough one too will hold him tack to's end,
This comes with wiving at threescore and three;
Would doting fools were all served so for me.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: To shut up all: Theophilus, take my niece,
We'll shortly find a lawful course to marry ye.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: I will take care for't. Arthur, take my daughter well bestowed.
With a glad father's blessing.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: And mine with it, wishing my daughter were as

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Sir take no thought for me, till my strict life
(By making man, and the world mere strangers to me,
In expiation of my late transgression
'Gainst maiden modesty) shall render me
Some way deserving th'honour of a husband.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Spoken like a good new woman.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: How now! do you look squeamish on your fortune,
Sir here's a gentleman shall maintain her blood
As worthy as your own till you defile it,
'Tis best you cleanse it again.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Cadzooks I will —
Forgive me for swearing, and turn precisian, and pray
I'the nose that all my brothers whoremasters spend no worse.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: My father —

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: O my child.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Though Mr. Quicksands made a mock-marriage with his English Moor,
I'll not mock thee.

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.l: Enough, enough. I hope all pleased at last
But master quicksands here.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I yield to fortune with an humble knee,
If you be pleased, your pleasure shall please me.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: Now let me be a modest undertaker
For us the players, the play and the playmaker:
If we have failed in speech or action, we
Must crave a pardon; if the comedy
Either in mirth, or matter be not right,
As 'twas intended unto your delight,
The poet in hope of favour doth submit
Unto your censure both himself and it,
Wishing that as you're judges in the cause
You judge but by the ancient comic laws.
Not by their course who in this latter age
Have sown such pleasing errors on the stage,
Which he no more will choose to imitate
Than they to fly from truth, and run the state.
But whether I avail, you have seen the play,
And all that in defence the poet can say
Is, that he cannot mend it by a jest
I'th epilogue exceeding all the rest;
To send you off upon a champing bit,
More than the scenes afforded of his wit:
Nor studies he the art to have it said
He skulks behind the hangings as afraid
Of a hard censure, or pretend to brag
Here's all your money again brought in i'th bag
If you applaud not, when before the word
'Twas parcelled out upon the shearing-board.
Such are fine helps; but are not practised yet
By our plain poet who cannot forget
His wonted modesty, and humble way
For him and us, and his yet doubtful play,
Which, if received or but allowed by you,
We and the play are yours, the poet too.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
